Came here during Dine About Town and got three courses for the special price. Prices for the vegetarian options especially, were pretty reasonable for an up-scale restaurant anyway. The people dining around us seemed a little pretentious, but the wait staff was super attentive and friendly. 

Nice atmosphere, great for a date. The risotto balls were delicious, had the linguine which was wonderful with a little kick and the chocolate mousse for desert-to dies for. Only wish the coffee ice cream scoop on top was bigger. Our waitress also gifted us a beet salad which was the app option we didn't choose off the Dine About Town Menu, which was a nice surprise. The wine list had nothing under $10.25/glass which I found a little annoying. 

Overall, nice place. A little out of the way, unless you happen to be in the area. And if I find myself there again, I will most likely stop back in.
author: J E.

description:
I lived about 3 blocks from garibaldis for over 3 years.  I never went here!  I always wanted to, but it never happened.  Keith finally made a reservation for dine about town this year.

Service was great.  Everything was great, but nothing surprising or so good I couldn't live another day without coming back.  The best thing was the olive plate served with the bread.  The meals are a good size which I love, I had the left overs for lunch today and probably tomorrow.

Not mind blowing, but pretty solid.
author: jessica b.

description:
They're self-described as a "second home" for the Bay Area elite --- Uhh, okay. What about wannabe Yelp elites?? ;) Much to my relief, the servers are down-to-earth and make the overall dining experience as comfortable and unstuffy as fine dining can be.

We started at the bar, where HH runs 5-6:30pm every single night. Seating at the bar is pretty limited (about 8 or so chairs), so get in early if you're planning on having drinks and appetizers anyway. Nice selection of beers, including bottles from a couple local breweries. 

----Food breakdown----
* Appetizer duet of risotto croquettes and chicken liver pate ($6.50/HH): 
Four croquettes come in a blanket of tomato coulis (fancy word for thick tomato sauce) and fontina; nice, crunchy coating but nothing worth reordering in the future. The chicken liver pate is molded with red wine gelee on top, served with crostini, coarse-ground dijon mustard and pickled fennel; the flavors were familiar but didn't mesh well together (and I tried every possible combination: pate+gelee+dijon+fennel, pate+dijon, pate+fennel, pate+gelee, gelee+fennel, and so on... no luck). 

* Marinated lamb tenderloin ($31.50): TASTIEST LAMB I'VE EVER HAD, and one of the best things I've eaten in quite some time. Marinated in Moroccan spices, each bite was so flavorful, succulent and juicy. Even though it was slightly overcooked (ordered medium, arrived medium-well), it didn't stop me from sneaking forkful after forkful of it from my bf's plate. Sides of couscous and romano beans completed the dish, although they faded into the background and were unable to compete with the lamb.

* Farmer's market menu ($29.95): Prix fixe menu consisting of an appetizer, entree and dessert, inspired by local ingredients. 
-- APP // An arugula salad topped with crunchy breadcrumb-coated chevre medallions provided a simple yet satisfying start. The wildflower honey drizzle (when inquired, was revealed to be from Marshall Farms) was a stunning addition. I need a bottle STAT!
-- ENTREE // Pork shoulder braised to tender perfection. The meat was lightly seasoned, allowing the porkiness to shine on its own. Served on a bed of thinly sliced polenta and sprinkled with tangy pomegranate seeds, the dish was elegant, though the flavors were almost too restrained to be committed to memory.
-- DESSERT // Rich, decadent, silky chocolate mousse with two freshly fried Italian doughnuts. As a dessert-shunning man, the bf heralded this as the best part of the FMM. The mousse was indulgent but surprisingly light; the doughnuts crisp, hot and fluffy.

Garibaldi's would get 3.5 stars were it not for the phenomenal lamb... It's the only thing truly worth coming for. Everything else (food, service, ambiance, price-point) seems replicable elsewhere.
author: Pauline D.

description:
Wow! What a fantastic happy hour! I've been coming here for three years and have never had a bad meal. The risotto croquettes, burger, and Island Breeze cocktail are by far my favorites on the happy hour menu (and are half off!). 

The only downside is a rude woman who takes reservations on the phone. When I called yesterday I asked if the 7pm or 9pm seating would be more amenable to a large party who was having a late lunch earlier that day. Her reply, "Do you really expect me to answer a question like that?" She then refused to answer any of my other questions. Maybe she was having a bad day, but regardless, they should have someone who is professional and courteous answering their phones. Poor form. Other than that though, great food, great atmosphere, and all around a great time.
author: Taylor F.

description:
I have been wanting to try Garibaldi's for awhile now and seeing them on the Dine About Town list encouraged me to jump on the opportunity. 

First thought...wow this place is actually bigger than it appears from the front...second thought...wow we are probably the youngest couple in here by about 30 years.

Despite the generation gap, Garibaldi's atmosphere was great, we had a very attentive waiter and the food was delicious. While my boyfriend opted for the Dine About Town menu of risotto croquettes (delicious cheesy balls) and linguini all'amatriciana (couldn't get enough even though I wanted to explode) I opted for the Farmer's Market special with a perfect wine pairing for just $12. 

I am a stickler for dessert and can't leave a dinner without it, so I was not let down when we shared the chocolate mousse with an Italian doughnut and chocolate lava cake. 

Would I go back...Yes, but maybe next time I will invite the parents.
author: Marika K.

description:
Best Dine About Town food I've had in a loooong time (long overdue review too!). Risotto croquettes for starters were actually really filling; nice crispy shell on the outside and chewy creamy risotto on the inside. I couldn't even finish all 4 of them actually because I wanted to leave room for the main entree. The chicken breast Milanese was tender and tasted great with the rich white wine caper sauce draped over it. I was impressed at how moist the chicken was. I also got to try the marinated lamb tenderloins. Best lamb I've ever had in my life. I usually HATE lamb because of that gamey taste, but this one had zero of that weird animal aftertaste. I was very impressed and definitely gained a new appreciation for lamb. Dessert was chocolate boudino, which to be honest, I don't quite remember. I think it was a little too rich for my palate so I finished half of it and called it a night.

Hope to visit here again soon for some special occasion!
author: Joyce H.

description:
I would have never thought to come here...as most restaurants in Presidio Heights seem stuffy to me. 
I ended up here on Saturday night for dinner before a movie. I was actually impressed by the food. We had the duck reillet which was pretty tasty..and we shared the Sole and the Filet Mignon for dinner--both were excellent. The waiter was pretty on point. Managed to get us in and out within an hour..just in time for our movie. 

One thing to note is that the tables are a bit crowded together...and the place can get a bit loud. The friendly patrons next to us jumped in on our conversation a few times..which I didn't mind. However, if you want privacy you may want to request seating at a free standing table.
author: Mimi T.

description: Great spot! Ambiance is welcoming, service is genuine, food is delicious!
author: Maria D.

description:
I grew up a few blocks away from here and have been going here for years. Garibaldi's is a restaurant that suites the style of Presidio/Laurel Heights. It's classy and fun yet intimate, expensive, and with a bit of snobbishiness mixed in.

Although the snobs of the area are not my favorite (often regulars there) this place is worth going to regardless. 

Get the Risotto Croquettes to start, holy shit they are good. The menu is good all around and although everything is expensive most of the dishes are brought to the level where you are willing to pay that much for them. The wine choices are great as well.

The one suggestion I have is that you make sure to mention you want a table that isn't sharing the booth seating on the first level when you make your reservation. It may not matter to you but it bothers me to be sitting so close to people that they can hear everything you are talking about and vice versa.

All around great place though.
author: Sam K.

description: Garibaldi's is great for lunch or dinner.  For lunch try the ahi tuna salad, or the grilled cheese which comes with salad and a cup of soup.  The greens are always fresh and the service is always good.  Best of all is the happy hour - 50% bar food and drinks.  The Monterey squid and a glass of pinot, for under $15.  Can't beat it.
author: Sandra M.

description:
LOVE this place. Love it because it's right across the street, when I'm being lazy. Love the risotto cakes. Love the chicken milanese. Love their wine. Love their desserts. Love the classy ambiance. 

It's pricey, but so worth it.

Perfect for a foggy night, followed by a movie around the corner.

Love.

UPDATE: Garbaldi's rocks my world even more. I was feeling "meh" on Monday and looking to stay in. So, I called in my order, and they let me take it out. Gourmet takeout? Sweeeet! :)
author: Alicia K.

description: Went there for anniversary dinner for the first time. Had a corner table. Great spot. Service was very fast and food was fantastic. Buffalo cheese, grilled calamari (fantastic), Steak and lamp. Great portions. All great and good wine selection
author: Aziz S.

description: This is may favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  It has a neighborhood locals, upscale, New York-y feel.  Best chicken, huge portions.....but soooo loud.
author: Barbara M.

description:
You get your money's worth! I came here for valentines day and they had a Prix Fixe menu. The food was amazing!! Starting with the appetizer to the main course and finishing it off with the dessert, the names and descriptions of the food were not the only things that were delicious. The food was to die for. The crowd that generally comes in is a lot of mid-age 30 and 30+. My date and I felt definitely out of place being the only 21 year olds. The wine selection is wide too. 

The ambiance of the place is very lovely. Very posh and elegant minus the bathrooms which are squished in the back of the restaurant. Literally, the space was so tiny and dark. The place itself is pretty narrow. There is a bar on one side and tables on the other; fits about 40 people max? The neighborhood/community in which the place is located is a very posh neighborhood. Very cute townhomes. I am definitely coming back here and explore the other items on the menu.
author: D S.

description:
Picked this restaurant based on Yelp reviews. Arrived at 5:30p with a reservation for our family of four.  Used the friendly valet parking ($10).  The hostess wasn't particularly friendly. "Do you have a reservation?" was the extent of the greeting. 
Table for four was in a decent location and the waiter was quick to offer drinks.  In the hour+ we were there the restaurant filled up, obviously the place to be!  Started out with a grilled calamari appetizer which was large enough for the four of us.
Four different entrees at our table. Salmon, filet mignon, pork chop, and chicken. All the entrees were presented well, were hot and given a decent sized portion.  The filet was served with oyster mushrooms which added nothing to the great tasting steak. Service was attentive and not intrusive. Liked the restaurant fine but wished there had been more choices on the menu. One pork dish, one chicken dish, one seafood dish, etc...get the point?  Passed on deserts as we were all full! I'd go back with my wife, but would leave the teenagers at home.
author: dan e.

description:
Lunch review: Great for business or if you just want a nice sit-down place.

Great food.  Great and friendly service.  Great vibe overall.

The food is not very challenging, but just made very well.  Here's a tasty list of what I like (but honestly I've never ordered anything bad):
*Buttermilk-pan fried chicken sandwich
*Garibaldis burger
*Portobella sandwich
author: Christine K.

description: Had to update since its been awhile. This place still rocks. Love when I find a neighborhood gem that is consistently tasty. Had the fried chicken salad at lunch. Dee-lish! And of course, anything with burrata and tomatoes is still awesome. And of course, it wouldn't be a visit to Garibaldis without ordering the chocolate budino with espresso gelato. Think I just gained a pound writing this.treat yourself. I don't get the 1 star reviews. This place has always been aces for us.
author: Bing B.

description:
Cute spot.  Great cocktails, nice and strong.  

Grilled calamari was good but the butter beans beneath were unseasoned.

The risotto balls are just so-so.  I was expecting them to be amazing based on the reviews but they were basically deep fried snacks with very little subtlety.  The accompaniment of beet salad and goat cheese was very good, however, it had hazelnuts which didn't make any sense.

I had the Loch Duarte salmon which was fine but not very flavorful.  I asked for some lemon and salt to pump it up.  The kale that came with it was great but I wasn't a big fan of the black rice.

The dessert was a big disappointment.  I had the chocolate budino and the consisetency of the budino was too gooey, like a raw brownie.  The ice cream on top and the sprinkling of hazelnuts was great but meal ended on a sour note.

Also, not a fan of the Quintessa wine.  Maybe it didn't go with my meal but it did not taste very smooth.
author: A S.

description: Watermelon salad, mission figs with goat cheese and 12 year aged balsamic, local heirloom tomatoes with burata and garlic toast, chicken milanese...all perfectly balanced with charming service as usual.  I'll never tire of you Garibaldis!
author: Tammy N.

description:
Some things never change. Garibaldi's is one of them. Old-school, classic Italian. Items on the menu could be from 1985 or 2011. What is lacking in innovation, is certainly made up for in execution. The flavors were impressive and the service attentive and welcoming. 
We were so happy with our meal that we came back after our movie to share some profiteroles and port. Interesting Italian twist on the classic French dessert. I am kicking myself that we didn't order two!
author: Michelle D.

description:
Nice place, great decor. Very good food, too. Over priced by about 20%, which is the main reason for the 3-star vs 4.

We went with a couple of friends from out of town and it was expensive enough that I felt bad that I had brought that but wasn't treating. I could have done some more homework before bringing them, but the type of food doesn't warrant the prices. The saving grace for me was the set menu offered for dinner, which gets you an app, very basic entree (baked ziti, for me, which probably had $4 of ingredients but was delicious), and dessert for $30. 

There was a huge, dead black fly on the surface of my ice water when the waitress set it on the table. And she didn't notice. I pointed it out when she came back and she just kind of laughed and said she'd get me another. Then left it there while she asked us if we wanted drinks, etc. I didn't want to make a big deal, but I expected a bigger deal to be made of it than that. Gross.

Service was solid otherwise, and the food was certainly good. Best to go if someone is paying for you, I'd say, but maybe good to include in a rotating list of other fancy (and maybe cheaper) places.
author: Phil K.

description:
Came to Garibaldi's for early Valentines Dinner with my sweetie, the food was very tasty and service was on point. We started with the Grilled calamari which was great and for dinner we had the chicken and lamb. Nothing to really complain about the food was good, wine list had a great selection and we had a nice time. Would also like to add the cocktails are GREAT...very strong! 

**Major downer was tables were very close together and we got sat next to a "power exec" who complained constantly about the LONG flight from LA to SF and stayed on his phone most of the dinner. I felt so bad for his date :( She was nice and we offered for her to sit with us when he excused himself to take yet another "important business call" at 9pm on a saturday night! We (his date included) all believed he was just trying to show off which she informed us had totally back fired on his ass! LOL!! ** Fun night
author: Tori M.

description: Amazing service with great flavorful food. We split the filet mignon following the warm kale salad and brussel sprouts. Oh...the brussel sprouts were divine! Really enjoyed this place.
author: Roy S.

description:
I can be harsh in noting places but this one was just a great place. The service is outstanding as well as the food and the wine list. I really appreciated that the waiter advised us a bottle which was not the most expensive one among the several ones I was interested in. We were 4 of us and were able to talk to each other even if the place was full, which is highly appreciated! We took the special menu of the restaurant week, but the milanese chicken (that I have heard of so many times before going there) is just amazing as well as the double expresso chocolate cake and the appetizer.

I would highly recommend it for a date or just being with your friends!

Be careful the restaurant closes at 9.30/ 10 pm in the beginning of the week, but a place I will keep in mind in SF for sure
author: Guillaume C.

description: Wonderfully warm and inviting, a real neighborhood feel. The food was wonderful, definitely try the potato starter-yummmmm. Service was exquisite, wine was perfect, all in all a great dinner.
author: Kim L.

description:
If I could effectively punch myself in the face, I would. Why? Because I lived mere blocks fro Garibaldi's for nearly five years, and ate there for the first time a month before I moved away from SF.

That was quite stupid of me. I write this review so you will not repeat my mistake.

Go eat here. For the service, which is stellar, welcoming and just the right blend of formal and informal. For the cocktails and wine, which are delicious, and in the case of wine, sometimes half off. But most of all, for the food.

I'm a huge fan of lamb, and the lamb here is the best I have ever eaten in my 34 years. Through my lamb-dominated memory, I recall both my wife's dish and our appetizers and desserts being wonderful, but the lamb is what's permanently etched into my brain. Seriously, it is the best lamb I have ever had. Ever. 

Thank you, Garibaldi's, for setting an impossibly high standard for the rest of the culinary world to probably fail to live up to.
author: Peter C.

description: There were more blue haired ladies in here than a Betty White gala, but hey, the food was par excellent.  We had a plateful of spanish peppers for an appy...they were charred perfectly. I had the lamb and hubby ordered the entree off the prix fixe menu...we were happy they let him do that.  All our courses were under-seasoned but that was an easy fix.  We'd go back for sure, especially when I become an octogenarian!
author: Steffanie S.

description: Love sitting at the bar, even just for a drink or two. the bartenders are quite friendly and it's nice to chat with the people in the neighborhood. The Garibaldi's burger is delicious, and I think it might be half off during Happy Hour. The "Chip Shot" is a tasty variation of the Irish Coffee.
author: Dan B.

description: Great flavorful food, fresh and delicious.  The service is also really good both times I was there.  I had the crab salad, steak, and a couple of apps + drinks.  Cocktails were awesome.  The food was very good.  The steak was a bit more chewy than I expected but still yummy.
author: C T.

description: Great neighborhood bistro.  Huge portions, even for someone as greedy as me, which in my book is usually synonymous with mediocre food, which this certainly is not.  This also extended to the wines by the glass, which were poured with extreme generosity and were not just excellent but reasonably priced too.  Very good service, relaxed and sophisticated atmosphere, well-lit (v important) and reasonable prices given quality and quantity -- there's really nothing not to like about this place
author: Chris R.

description: Nothing special about the food.  The space is elegantly modern and cocktail menu is good.
author: Eric C.

description:
DEEEELICIOUS!!! great ambiance, great service - even saw and spoke with the executive chef for a few minutes! john, i think his name is, chatted up a few tables - hilarious guy, so creative. recommended a new dessert for us to try... can't remember the name but it was a lemony sorbet with blueberries and a thin crispy candy brittle on the side. to die for.

apps were good - do the pork belly and tuna. 

entrees are great sizes and amazing as well. i did the scallops which were not fishy at all. great soupy sauce, veggies, just simple and delicious.

will definitely go again, easy parking too! bringing friends from out of town the next time i go!
author: Noreen S.

description:
this review is for happy hour only!

i haven't been to many happy hours, but this one has some pretty decent prices and food to offer. came here with some of the girls, to have small appetizers and some pretty powerful drinks.

we had risotto croquettes, sardines, deep fried chiles and some sort of vegetable tempura. it was all pretty decent and fresh. i loved the risotto croquette it had a nice crunchy exterior and it had a unique flavor to it, sort of hard to describe but it was really good. 

the drinks were pretty powerful, i had the island breeze it was a combination of pineapple juice and 5x distilled vodka, very good but strong. my friend had the pomegrante cosmo and loved it, you can taste pomegrante juice but it wasnt over powering it was a good balance of juice and vodka!
author: Stella J.

description: Very good food, nice little place. Good date spot or casual spot for couples. Some unique dishes too.
author: Michael R.

description:
SO this was one of my favorite local restaurants to go with my husband but now I'm having second thoughts of returning anytime soon. Apart from it being so much louder than normal we kept having to catch and hold our sparking water still every so often from being knocked over by the waiter standing in between the tables.
We went for date night because I was craving their chicken milanese dish. 
Its outstanding. I noticed that they were participating in Dine about town and usually in years past they menu has been extremely limited. This time it looked quite substantial so I thought maybe I would peruse the menu and see whether it was a better deal to order al a carte or the fixed menu. 
I had questions. "What is the soup of the day?" which was one of the first options. 
I was replied with "its the same as on the main menu" "Everything is the same as the main menu"
I replied "So what is the soup of the day?"
Again replied the waiter " Its the same as the main menu" 
On the main menu was written... SOUP OF THE DAY. It really felt like a scene from Dumb and Dumber. MMM soup de jour sounds yum Ill have one of those.
My husband asks " What is the soup of the day?" 
replied with " Leek and potato." 
Wow it really took that long to get an answer. I should have asked the table next to us.
I wouldn't have normally gotten a starter but I thought the Dine about town thing must be a better deal so why not.
I started with the salad with pear an gorgonzola and it was great. Chicken for my main and then the Chocolate budino for desert. As it was pointed out several times to me when we were ordering EVERYTHING was the same as the main menu. But it wasn't.
They totally scammed us with the desert portion. I felt a little ripped off. The Chocolate Budino that my husband and I share every single time we go there had miraculously shrunk from regular size to a tiny little ramekin portion. 
Wow what a deal.
Salad $9.50
Chicken $21.50
Budino $10 (real sized)
= $41 
Apparently a savings of $6. I think not. No deal here.
Looking at the menu online we were obviously given the petite Budino worth maybe $6 at best. So overall a savings of $2. Really?
The dine about town menu is great for restaurants trying to get people to spend more than they usually do and get less in the process. If you want a great Chicken dish then this is your place. But don't get conned into eating or spending more than you normally would.

On a side note, when the table on our left sat down to order and the lovely lady asked what the soup of the day was, it wasn't leek and potato, so who knows what it really was.
author: Melody M.

description: One of the few consistent spots in the Pac Heights/Presidio Heights neighborhood. The menu has a lot of choices. Solid spirit and wine list. Great desserts. The place is normally packed with residents of the 2 neighborhoods. Make a reservation. Eating at the bar is also a good option.
author: Jay D.

description:
Wow! I am still craving the Chicken Milanese and it's been a week since I got it. I'm going to be honest, I didn't know what Chicken Milanese was until I ordered it but it was amazing. 

My friend and I have been using OpenTable to book reservations at restaurants around the city that either (a) we have always wanted to try or (b) we have heard great things about. Reservations were fairly easy to get (probably because the place is so big) and it was only a short walk to fun Lower Pac Heights bars after we finished.

 Add this to your "must-try" list in SF!!
author: Amanda S.

description: Excellent food, great service. One of the consistently stellar SF restaurants.
author: Sarkis S.

description:
Garibaldi's really *is* doing something right.  I don't think it's a place that anyone gets too excited about because it has been around for so long, but there's no real reason they shouldn't.  We stopped in unannounced on a Saturday, and they eventually found a nice little table by the window for us.  Very warm, very cozy.  We just ordered a couple of small things (not too hungry that evening): soup, salad, an appetizer, and the chocolate budino      for dessert.  It was all nice.  The service was outstanding -- there when you needed it, gone when you didn't.  Very professional.  My hat's off to them all.

P.S. Garibaldi's, if you read these reviews, you might want to check to make sure that the cocktail prices on the menu match what your computer spits out on the tab.  No biggie, but i think there may have been a small error or two.
author: Laurence W.

description:
The Chicken Milanese is singly one of the best dishes available in SF. Crispy, juicy, lemony, salty, rich and I have not even begun to describe the accompanying mashed potatoes. The kitchen makes capers sing. 

The rest of the menu can be spotty (some are treasures, some blah). Mildly overpriced - but hey, that's the neighborhood. Wines by the glass aren't cheap but they are usually well chosen and give you a generous pour. Service usually good but the place can get downright busy.
author: Ben S.

description:
One of the best happy hours in the city. Up there with Orson's. 

My Manhattan was incredible except for the ice they use.
My burger was pretty good.

The service was amazing! They were so friendly!
author: Christopher L.

description:
This is one of my favorite San Francisco Restaurants.

A  " first class"  operation with superb cuisine  

Highly professional management and staff.
author: Jon B.

description:
I was heading in expecting decent food.  I was really amazed.  I went with a large group and there was much sampling and sharing.  We had a pork-belly & watermelon dish with peppers, and a marvelous reduction.  Stunning!

Every entree we had was spot on and well presented.

Dessert rather made me take pause.  We had one of everything.  My personal favorite was the walnut and caramel drizzled, espresso ice cream sandwiches.  But the take on Baked Alaska was lovely.  There was a bit of berry loveliness inside the ice-cream.  

Rather a non-pretentious store front, but cozy interior and well worth a trip across the city to enjoy.
author: Memesmith N.

description: After about twenty excellent dining experiences within a year, I can say it's the best.  Just don't tell everyone at the same time.
author: Simons C.

description:
Dinner Wednesday night was a delight. Excellent appetizers (the chick pea and feta salad, and the Pappas Bravas (crisp fried potatoes in a mildly spicy sauce) led to perfectly braised short ribs. And be sure to try the Tom Waits cocktail (Buffalo Trace, Benedictine and bitters, chilled, served neat). Service was attentive and the portions of everything a very good value. 

Garibaldis is a quintessential SF neighborhood place. Well done.
author: Mark A.

description:
Garibaldi's has been my favorite for years.  It is situated in the lovely Sacramento Street neighborhood.  There is valet parking or parking on the street.  The staff is very accommodating and the atmosphere lively.  I have been here with friends, and with family where a wheelchair was being used.

I am truly happy with almost every meal I've had, but the menu is sparse.
There is a full bar and a very good list of wines. They are well known for the chicken Milanese which is ample!  The hamburgers are great and the pate, wonderful.    Reservations are always a must.  If you are looking for a romantic quiet place, this is not it.  It is very busy and can be quite noisy, but that won't stop me from coming back!
author: Rose J.

description: I went here last night as a walk-in with a friend. We waited for a bit and were seated at a somewhat cramped table, but it was entirely fine considering that we were walk-ins on a Saturday night. Great service, great food (I had beet salad and the butternut squash ravioli with sage) and zero attitude. A great experience all around.
author: Diane O.

description: Garibaldi's is consistently one of the finest dining experiences in SF.  Their staff, food, ambience, the whole shabangabang is top-notch.  If it's your first time: don't miss their immense selection of fine wines, the lamb tenderloin, and antipasti.  My girl and I have had basically the entire menu and nothing has disappointed.  Expensive, and worth it.
author: Ryan H.

description: Admittedly it has been a few years since we've eaten here but it did not disappoint! The food was delicious and the service was very good. We used to eat here alot when we lived in the city and its still a favorite.
author: B B.

description:
Ate here a few weeks back and all I remember is that it was worth remembering!

I stole some "braised pork tagine with creme fraiche" off of my friends plate, which I very much enjoyed (he got the $29 prix fixe). Never had anything quite like it! 

I got the chicken breast milanese....WOW  it was finger-licking good and lightly pan fried....giant portion..... Super Duper yum! Next to SPRUCE this is my other new neighborhood favorite!
author: Lee M.

description:
Just fantastic, on every count.

Three of us went for dinner since it was within walking distance of our friend's place, not really knowing much about it.  (We had no trouble getting an 8:30 reservation for the same night.)  We were immediately seated by a friendly & welcoming hostess who also offered to take our jackets.  Within a few minutes of sitting down, we had water, bread, and some extremely tasty olive tapenade (which I had to restrain myself from devouring all of).

Initially, we started with cocktails & all of us were very happy with our selections (Ginger Julep, The Right Thyme, and a vodka/pear drink that I can't remember the name of).  For appetizers, my boyfriend and I split the risotto croquettes & the grilled calamari.  The croquettes were pretty good but not amazing; the calamari was some of the best I've ever had - fresh, perfectly cooked, and very flavorful.  Our other friend ordered the 29.99 Farmer's Market menu; his heirloom tomato, cantaloupe, & frise salad was excellent.

For mains, I had the lamb tenderloin, which was also some of the best (if not *the* best) I've ever had.  Perfectly cooked, marinated in something absolutely delicious, and served with excellent couscous & a tasty sauce.  Also, I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised by the amount of lamb that showed up.  There were three good-sized chunks of meat, and as tasty as it was, I couldn't finish it all & was forced to pawn it off on my bf & friend (who were good sports & finished it up for me).

My bf had the duck confit, which was tender, lean (rare for duck), and also perfectly cooked, and served with some very tasty corn, tomatoes, & other veggies.  The Farmer's Market menu entree was a delicious, super-fresh pasta dish with lots of tasty veggies & bit of tasty meat (pancetta?  Not sure).  We were all very pleased with our selections  & there was much passing around of bites.  We hadn't intended to get wine, but it turned out they're running a wine promotion through labor day where all bottles are half off, so we decided to go with a bottle of Aglianico ($30 instead of $60), which was very good.

The Farmer's Market menu dessert was two scoops of fruit sorbet (one peach, one raspberry) and a ginger cookie, all of which was incredibly tasty (the peach sorbet was especially amazing).  My boyfriend had the hot toddy drink off the dessert menu, which was a bit disappointing - it didn't have as much flavor as we expected and was a bit watery.

A couple of other notes - lots of reviews mentioned that the place is very loud and that the tables too close together.  I disagree.  I'd say the volume is about average for a SF dinner spot of that size, and we didn't have any trouble hearing each other or the server.  Also, the tables were about as close together as anywhere else in the city.  Not a problem at all.  Also, we had fabulous & friendly service all evening.  (And dude who said it was too hard to find & had to drive around the block 3 times before he saw it?  Not sure what your issue is.  The name of the place is written on the front window in huge block letters.)

Overall, absolutely amazing.  Yes, it was a $250 meal between the three of us after tax and tip, but worth every penny.  Will definitely have to keep it in mind for future fancy dinners.
author: Angela B.

description: So Garibaldi's has been a long time San Francisco neighborhood restaurant that has received pretty ratings, but I sadly didn't feel the same. From an interior standpoint, the place is quite nice and not overdone. It's comfortable and sleek. However, from a food and service standpoint, it was just ok. Total bummer because I was expecting some solid SF deliciousness. Service was fairly inattentive. Our server was nice but appeared totally detached. She asked one question that she repeated 3 times (which were the only times we saw her). "how is everything...is there anything else you need?" She wasn't there to get our order for our second round of drinks, and forgot about our appetizers, and it took like 20 minutes to get olives that we ordered when we were seated. Next, the food. For starters we shared a salad, which was a standard spring mix, then we ordered the burrata with toasted bread, and you can' t really go wrong with burrata. For a third app we ordered the grilled calamari with white beans. It was tasty but not exciting to eat. For dinner I was torn between the lamb tenderloins and the seared tuna. I went with the lamb, which was delicious, but the cous cous it was served with was dry....super super dry. Like corn meal texture dry. Unfortunately, the cous cous was also dry on my aunts order. Garibaldis, did we catch you on an off night? Since I don't come to SF all that often, I most likely won't come back here on my next trip, with all the options in the city.
author: Isabella J.

description:
My family went here for Mother's Day because it's one of my sister's favorite restaurants over the past few months.  To this day it amazes me how she could speak so highly of the restaurant.  My husband & I walked into a half filled restaurant. As we were escorted to our table we kept walking and walking till we were at THE back of the restaurant.  There were only two tables of Asians in the entire restaurant, one being our table, and the other right next to us.  Can we say RACIAL PROFILING!!!  Normally I would ask to be moved before I even got to the back of the restaurant, but my folks didn't want to cause a scene since they had already been seated for ten minutes.  

I started mumbling under my breath, but tried to make the best of it.   When the water was served, there was a bug floating around in my glass.  Our waitress sweetly apologized and got another glass for me.  After the food was served, my husband noticed that his steak was bloody raw and not the warm medium that he ordered.   I don't think I will ever be coming back to this place.  It was definitely one of THE worst dining experiences that I've had a really long time.  I have been using Yelp for a few years now and have finally been so distraught that I felt I must log in and write my first negative dining review.
author: Stacey L.

description: Hot diggity dog!  This was some yummy, yummy food!  I'm one lucky lady because we just so happened to stumble upon this spot and were able to get a table on a Saturday night.  The pork belly/tenderloin was fabu, the burrata and tomato salad simply beautiful - on the plate and in my tummy!  Service was good, but just tepid enough to merit 4 stars versus 5.  Extremely generous portion sizes, creative cocktails.  I have already recommended this spot to others.
author: Kim H.

description:
4 stars overall, but 3-3.5 for the Dine About Town menu. 
Location - this restaurant at night is completely hidden. My friend and I drove around the block at least 3 times before calling the restaurant asking for specific details about location. Tricky!

Interior - dimly lit, very loud. Packed on a Saturday evening. Interesting pictures hanging on the walls.

Service - pretty good service. They gave us more bread/tapenade when we asked for it. A few of us got the wine pairing, and we had to remind our waitress for our second pairing. Knock one star...

Food - DAT menu: no selection for each course, $29.99.  (Wine pairing add $12 for 2 glasses) Blood orange salad was nicely plated, tasty, very healthy. Entree was a clam linguini - by itself, I guess it was pretty flavorful, pasta was cooked al dente (but compared to food on the regular menu...was underwhelming). Dessert was chocolate budino (sp?) - really satisfying, with robust espresso ice cream on top, sprinkled with caramelized nuts. 

Two friends ordered off the DAT menu - one got the chicken, the other the lamb. OMG. The lamb here is the best I've ever tasted. I've tried lamb before, and was never a big fan. This dish, however, was amazing. So incredibly tender, full of non-gamey flavor. Incredible. 5 stars for the lamb. The chicken was succulent and buttery, paired nicely with the mashed potatoes. In order of food, 1. lamb. 2. chicken. 3. linguini with clams.

I'd come back here just for the lamb.
author: Carol L.

description:
Love the neighborhood, love the size of the restaurant, love the understated decor.  Everyone in our party enjoyed their dishes.  My hubby got frantic when he scanned the menu and there was no vegetarian main course item.  I told him to relax.  A good chef always has a tasty vegetarian dish in her back pocket for patrons like me who insist on ordering off the menu.  I wasn't disappointed here.  The server brought out a plate of roasted/steamed veggies (cauliflower, green beans, mushrooms, brussel sprouts, butternut squash) in an excellent light sauce.  I savored every single bite!

Being the margarita fan I am, I ordered the Sudie's margarita on the cocktail menu.  A bit sour and a bit light on the tequila and cointreau.  On the other hand, my glass of Kent Rasmussen Pinot Noir was perfect.
author: Blue L.

description:
We came in here very briefly the other night before seeing The Hangover at  The Vouge across the street for a quick drink and a bite at the bar.  The main reason I'm writing this review is because Jack, our bartender, was very cool, welcoming and gave us stellar service. 5 stars to Jack.

Other than that- I've been coming here for YEARS, always have a great experience and it's a perfect date spot.  Their eggplant caponatina tastes like Chinese sweet and sour pork however, which was weird...minus 1 star.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
I would have given it more stars but the service is extremely slow (I've eaten lunch and dinner there numerous times) and the wait staff is uppity. It's definitely a "ladies who lunch" place where you can spend easily 2 hours eating because you are waiting so long for your first course. 

At lunch today, my guest ordered ice tea which took at least 20 minutes to arrive. I had to ask the waitress and she gave me this snoddy look. The hardest person working there was the ever-friendly asian man who refills your water glass and brings you bread. I hope he gets a share of the tips. The bread, I must say, is pretty awesome - the walnut bread and the olive bread. I could make a meal out of just the bread. The wines by the glass are pricey. The portions are generous and well plated.

It's a very nice restaurant - it just reeks of attitude and slow service. I guess if you live in that neighborhood, you can spend 2 hours at lunch and longer at dinner.
author: Jacqueline P.

description:
We have always adored this restaurant in the past. 

The food is mostly ok now. The service is good, but the people at the door are really, really snobs!         And they just work there! 

I really wonder if John knows what is going on! The last time we were there we had an early reservation at 6:30. Guess what! The restaurant was almost empty, about eight tables occupied and five people at the bar. The hostess wanted to seat us upstairs! I told the hostess that was not what I wanted. She gave me such attitude and such a look! 

We were finally given a table on the lower level right next to the wall and steps. I asked about all the empty tables toward the windows, and she told me that they were all reserved. I guess the other reservations they have are much more important then ours. 

NONE OF THE TABLES TOWARD THE FRONT WINDOWS WERE OCCUPIED for over an hour. Save these for the VIP's must be the new working motto! I was very upset and angry as you can tell. I have never been treated like this at this restaurant before! Oh how I miss John and his sister! 

I wlll not be going back anytime soon!
author: Gean T.

description: Everything here is awesome -- including the service! Go to here. I had the pasta dish with corn and proscuitto: amazing! I had to go here for a corporate event, and I will DEFINITELY be returning.
author: Sherry Z.

description: Disappointed.  Ordered a 2011 merry Edwards from Russian river and they served 2011 from sonoma coast without telling us and wanted the same price
author: keith A.

description:
unexpected surprises.

plastic green frogs, great conversation and best of all good company.

last minute apps and a bottle of delicious sirah. 

hummus, risotto balls, calamari, eggplant.

I can't wait to come back and have dinner. love the ambiance and romantic feeling you get by candlelight.
author: Lily M.

description:
I decided to make a reservation here for my birthday dinner after reading numerous reviews of different places on yelp. From start to finish, this was a winner! We were going to be about 15 minutes late and called ahead to let them know - even though the restaurant was packed they were very accommodating. **Note to restaurant-goers: If you call ahead that you'll be late, you will almost never lose your reservation.** 

The food was EXCELLENT. We had an amazing appetizer of watermelon, fried pork belly, and cilantro. Sounds strange, tastes AMAZING. Every entree was fantastic and the drinks were delightful. Service was great as well: neither over- nor under-attentive and very knowledgeable. 

This place is very classy and chic -- and you definitely pay for it. But if you're willing to spend a few extra $, you will not be disappointed!
author: Catherine E.

description: Charming location and cute restaurant.  Staff was friendly and efficient.  Food was yummy.
author: Lev E.

description:
Do you LOVE ladies who lunch? Do you LOVE delicious salads in a quaint atmosphere? Then, this is the place for you. 

I always pass Garibaldi's when I'm traversing the city from Marina southward. When I've glanced at the dinner menu, it always seemed a bit pricey. However, the lunch menu looked perfect! 

I took my mom here after I booked a day-of reservation via opentable.com. She had the seared ahi and I had the DELICIOUS lamb salad. For $42, it was a very nice sit down lunch where the server didn't rush us and was very helpful in regards to the menu. 

I would do it again.
author: Misha F.

description:
Everything is fab! Food and service.

Get the burger during the week, its perhaps not on the menu ? Their cocktails are great too!
author: renee m.

description:
Great food. Great atmosphere. For me, they straddle the line between nice and stuffy really well. I've been there wearing a shirt and tie and shorts and flip flops and been equally comfortable. They also don't mind you sitting at the bar and enjoying a glass of wine. It's usually pretty easy to get a table. 

I've been there about a half dozen times and the food is always fresh with quality ingredients. It's not the most adventurous menu but if you're looking for geniune, uncomplicated dishes, this place has it.
author: Joe W.

description: Amazing happy hour - get the Risotto croquettes, half price Kobe beef burgers (only $7) and a half price cocktail. Best meal ever and I try to do it as often as possible.
author: Patrick S.

description:
Ducked in here for a weekday lunch with my mom and grandma after going on the University House Tour. I was really surprised to find a sophisticated and classy restaurant. It was filled to the brim with the ladies-who-lunch crowd, but really, who else is going to be having a long lunch in Laurel Heights on a Tuesday? 

Our adorable server was attentive and never intrusive. We all ordered the lobster quesadilla was was amazing, and I sipped on an elderflower Italian soda. I stole a bit of my mom's lemonade and it was delicious as well! We finished our lunch by splitting the cherry and rhubarb crumble topped with incredibly flavorful vanilla bean ice cream. It was one of the loveliest lunches I've had in a long time. I should play hooky from work more often....
author: Kelly C.

description:
Big, big fan of this place. Had a reservation so can't comment on the wait, but the place was pretty busy for a Wednesday night. We were seated immediately, even though we were early, and all the servers were very friendly. Service was good, absolutely no complaints, and it was amazing how much they DIDN'T rush you. Even at other nice restaurants I always feel to some degree they'd like to keep you moving (makes sense, but still). 

As for the food, I can't say enough good things about the portions. I guess I'm in the minority (I like the think the silent majority) in that I don't think paying more should mean getting less food. It doesn't make the food tastier, it doesn't make the restaurant classier, and it doesn't make sense (You're paying for ambiance, service, location and food, and I know nicer restaurants use better quality foods, but there is no way that paying $30 means they can only afford to serve you 6 oz of meat). Anyways, Garibaldi's doesn't fall into this category. AND, the food was good. We liked 3 of the 4 things we got, and I can't say the 4th wasn't tasty, it just wasn't what we liked. Here's what we ate:

Summer Tomatoes (Starter) - Awesome. It made a great appetizer. 

Calamari (Starter) - Awesome again. Delicious calamari, good sauce, and again, a good portion. 

Bucatini Puttanesca (Main) - This was the one thing we weren't a huge fan of. It was very olive'y, and just had a lot going on, but certainly nothing wrong with it. Just not for us. 

Chicken Milanese (Main) - Back to being awesome. This was actually far and away the best. Chicken was great, the crust was awesome, and the mashed potatoes matched. 

Would definitely recommend this place. It's well above average in all categories.
author: Patrick M.

description: This is a truly neighborhood gem. Ambience, food and service are great. I would definitely recommend it for a romantic dinner. Valet service is available, but with a little bit of luck, nearby street parking shouldn't be that hard.
author: Steve E.

description:
I never-never-ever order chicken when I go out to eat... The chicken is BOMB.COM

Advice, Bring a bottle of wine and pay the corkage.   Start with the grilled calamari, and have the chicken or lamb, and make sure to save room for the dessert.
author: Chris B.

description: This place is fantastic!  Wonderful ambience, exellent service, and delicious food!   I think their menu changes, but every item we ordered, from appetizer to entree, was consistently good - which is very difficult to do.  The salmon, which I don't usually like, was excellent.  The pork tenderloin and beef short ribs were also delicious.  The dishes are not cheap, but are reasonably priced for the quality.  It's great place for a quiet, romantic dinner.  Like most places in SF, parking can be a pain.  All things considered,  I was thoroughly pleased and will be back!
author: Winnie D.

description: Boyfriend & I came here for dessert, we ordered the trio petite bites - 2 Chocolate Budino's & 1 Chocolate Truffle Gelato. Best desert I've ever had in my entire life! Can't wait to go back for dinner.
author: Beeta O.

description: A nice Italian spot 3 blocks from home. Their happy hour, from 5-6:30, is half off the inside of the bar menu (6 wines, 6 cocktails, 6 beers and a variety of small bites). The best deal is the burger at the bar for $7, although I've never tried it. The cosmo is too sweet but the sauvignon blanc was perfect. Warm olives are also served at the bar. The hummus is chunky and lacks flavor. Older dinning crowd overall, but happy hour is still pretty fun. I'd bring my parents when they are in town next to try the full menu
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
I came here with my husband and two friends on a Friday night.  2 of us chose the Dine About Town menu, and the other two deviated.  I will start my review with my take on the DAT menu.  Unfortunately, I chose the DAT menu, and I was extremely disappointed in my Clam Linguine entree.  It lacked flavor, and it came to the table cold.  The restaurant also did not offer any entree choices like other participating DAT restaurants do.  Had I based my review solely on the DAT menu, this restaurant would have received a 2-star review.

However, my husband ordered the Lamb Tenderloin (not on the DAT menu), and it was fantastic.  It was the best piece of lamb I've ever tasted.   I wish I had deviated and ordered this instead.  My other friend ordered the chicken breast which was very flavorful as well.

Dine About Town lures new patrons in to try restaurants and foods they may not always try otherwise.  I think that if you participate in this program, you really should put your best food forward to make people want to come back again.  Garibaldi's is lucky that our party deviated from the DAT menu because otherwise, none of us would ever come back.  I'd recommend coming to this restaurant and ordering from their regular menu.  

Also, the restaurant is very dark and hard to find as you're strolling down the street.  We drove by twice before we spotted the valet man that we assumed worked for the restaurant.
author: Linh L.

description:
Very charming restaurant in great location.
I took my GF here for her birthday dinner last night.
We thought this place was new but it's has been here for 18 years.
Very clean nice interior.
Dinner entries were $20 to $36.
a glass of red zinfandal, $9
No salmon but sea bass, $26
We had a fried calamari, $14
My GF had Pan fried skin less Chicken, $22.
I had Spare Ribs, $27
Big sized dish and very rich flavored sauce.
We were stuffed.
Great service, every thing was just fine.
Nothing wrong.
Customers were all clean-cut people.
We had a good dinner.

So why just 3 stars?
Because I had better dinner before spending less than $120 for 2. 
That's all.

I think the food was... taste too rich and over priced.
Every items are at least about $5 over priced if you compare with other restaurants, Seriously!

I was thinking about it. $120 for 2, romantic dinner?
The food was good but I expect more for that.
There are many better options are available in the city.
Maybe I am just a cheap Asian doesn't fit in the restaurant. 

I don't think I'll come back.
Once is enough.
Let me put this way, you'll be enjoy a lot more if your date payin'.
I'll definitely try some where else TO SAVE MY MONEY AND GET BETTER FOOD!!

I'd like to say this place is a perfect dinner date or family gathering only for riches in the neighborhood. 
But I have to say, The wait stuffs are 1st class well trained-pro, never go wrong to the customers. You can count on their service at least.

By the way, I actuary over heard a white man, in 30's was sitting the other table said to his guests of two, maybe his mom & pap, " Obama? No way! C'mon, This is America. We don't need a black president." and on to say crap about Democrats, what a dick head racist he was. made me sick just been there. Yup, racism is still here around the corner in the great safe neighborhood in SF.

P.S., When I made a reservation at Ristaurante Milano for my GF's birthday year ago, they gave her a small tiramisu with a candle on it,  without asking, that was really sweet. We had a nice & warm dinner at Ristrante Milano.
But this place, I made a reservation exact same way I did to Milano, mentioned her birthday dinner, but Nothing happened in here.
author: Nobu K.

description:
Lovely little restaurant in Laurel Heights. Everyone at the table enjoyed their meal and the desserts were pretty good. It ended up being pretty pricey given my socks weren't blown off...but I think that is from the $14 cocktails. The drinks were almost as expensive as the entree and not different than any other bar. 

Order a bottle of wine instead is my recommendation. 

I'd been wanting to try our Garibaldi's for awhile and I'm glad I did. It just won't be one I regular. 

ps- Little known fact, the Garibaldi is the California state fish
author: Jennifer W.

description: Had dinner here a few weeks ago and it was awesome.  Great wine menu, and the food was simple and delicious.  Great date-night location.  Clientele is a taaad on the older side, but the restaurant is cozy with great service.  As others suggest, get the calamari, it's amazing.
author: Kelli D.

description:
ARRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRUUUUUUUU -im yepling at the moon because i love this place more than words!

with over 31 reviews there is not much to be said- i just need to add it to may favorite restaurant list (and this is a global list - not to be mixed with individual cities list, which, i do not have yet b/c i sort of have this thing called a job, which, TOTALLY gets in the way of my reviewing). 

my trips to san francisco are not trips unless i get to garibaldi's for the lamb tenderloin. on a few RARE occasions i have ordered other items. they are, as the lamb, ALWAYS STELLAR. 

Now, if only they offered a frequent dining card? Life would be perfect!
author: Deidre H.

description: I like the dark ambiance, reminds me of spruce.  It has larger small plates.  The grilled calamari was very nice.  The beet plate was a bit odd with granola, but i love beets. Asparagus was too fishy for me and of course you can't go wrong with buratta. The warm olive bread and tapenade is a very nice touch.  Can't recall a time dining where the bread served was olive.
author: Caroline L.

description:
Solid satisfying dining experience: great ambiance, service, food, and drinks. Everyone was happy with it upon departure so it's really encroaching on 4.5+ stars.

Highlights:
- Nice design: from the black logo writing on the front window, to the brightly colored paintings of fruit on the walls, to the rectangular paper lanterns hanging by the bar, this place exudes modern class.
- Balanced feel: elegant but not stuffy; refined but very comfortable; neighboorhoody but not too casual; small but enough tables; popular and full, but not chaotic and plenty of room to breathe.
- Risotto croquettes: big hit of the night for the table. Meatball sized fried balls that just ooze steam and cheese when you cut into them with a fork.
- Chicken breast milanese: huge portion, great thickness (not too thick not too thin), lightly fried with an herb breadcrumb crust. A simple dish perfected. 
- Carrot soup: pure pureed carrots. Loved that there wasn't any cream. Had a bit of nutmeg taste too it so almost pumpkin soupy in a bowl.
- Halibut: was worried when it came out pure white, as I'm used to seeing color from it seared or baked a bit, but the pure fresh flavor was there when I bit into it. Nice sized thick piece and came with herbed spaetzel which was different and I liked cause it reminded me of our Germany trip last year. ;-)
- Dessert: not sure what it was called but it was really fantastic! A big bowl of coffee ice cream with chocolate and crunchy hazelnuts. Sounds basic but it really shined.
- Limoncello: my fave surprise of the evening. Just like when you're in Italy, we were presented with a little tall shot glass full of house made limoncello. Awesome! Sealed the deal for this place and I being good friends.
- Excellent service: from the hostess to the bartender to the waitress, all were pure professionals. Bartender was friendly while masterfully mixing and serving up cool drinks. Waitress was knowledgeable about their food and wine and did things like fold up lap napkins when someone got up and slip in a glass of wine on the table to not interrupt conversation.
- Deals: even without dine about town going on, they have a regular 3 course set meal for $29.95 listed in the top right corner. Even ordering off the main menu was affordable for a nice SF resturant.
- Nice drink menu: I had one with muddled strawberries and champagne and the hub had a pineapple infused martini (he's a beer guy but was trying to be nice to me so I could try both). Friend had a blueberry mojito with real blueberries presented in a tall glass.

Lowlights (my flip side to highlights):
- Neighboorhoody so bit hard to get to/park and kind of a destination in itself. Doesn't seem like an area you'd visit to spend an evening of dinner and drinks after, etc. 

Without knowing much about the place, was an excellent dinner choice we tried during dine about town and we'll definitely be back.
author: Eve K.

description:
Is it true that the composer Schumann had to be institutionalized because he couldn't get this one note out of his head?  Well, if so, the same thing just might happen to me, but with a dish I had at Garibaldi's - Ravioli stuffed with eggplant and leek, and smothered in this velvet-like red pepper cream sauce.  I can't stop thinking about it!  

Dinner at Garibaldi's on Friday night was a pleasure all around.  The restaurant is intimate and romantic, and a little dressy, which I liked.  It's very "adult" - no one here cares about trends or popularity - and you can tell that they have spent years honing their skills both in the kitchen and with the service.  They make sure you have everything you want, only making suggestions when asked, and taking extra care that the meal goes smoothly and seamlessly.

Since we were going to a party afterwards, we just had cocktails rather than wine.  My friend had a Lavender Martini, and I had the Garibaldi's Salty Dog.  Both were wonderful and I am curious to try the other libations on the menu - another time, for sure.

Since neither of us had been there before, my friend and I decided to try a sampler of every item on the antipasti platter, which consisted of:  dates stuffed with bleu cheese, in balsamic vinegar with chopped pistachios, proscuitto, brushetta, and lemon basil hummus with crostini.  This was a very nice introduction into the Cal-Med cooking - and all items were delicious, with our absolute favorite being the dates.

We both wanted the same thing for dinner - the Ravioli.  Usually when someone orders what I want, I order something different just so that we can taste both, but we both REALLY wanted the ravioli.  We were so glad we did - we were both members of the Clean Plate Club after dinner!  The ravioli was so fresh and tender, and that sauce, oh, that sauce!

I liked the fact that you could get the pasta and risotto dishes in half orders if you wanted to eat more lightly.

Perfect for a business dinner, date, anniversary, parents in town (especially if your parents are discerning and difficult - they seem like they can handle it), or a long talk with a friend.

Well done, Garibaldi's, hope to see you soon!
author: Liz S.

description: This charming Presidio Heights dining spot offers outstanding Californian-Mediterranean fare, but it's a tad too pricey to become more than a special-occasion destination. As good as a salad of mixed greens, candied walnuts, fresh pears, and gorgonzola splashed with balsamic vinaigrette is, it's too small to justify a price tag of $7.95. Marinated lamb tenderloins in a tarragon sauce are exquisite, as are the pistachio couscous and haricots vert served with them, but again there's not enough of any of it to make the dish worth $29.95. Nor is the portion of tender beef short ribs in red wine sauce, with sides of navy beans and roasted fennel, large enough to command $26.95. And nowhere is iced tea worth $3.50. Service is excellent, as it should be when your tab is as high as this.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
Hm I can't say that I was am impressed as I should have been with Garibaldi's.  Lara and I went here and it's a nice spot on Presidio technically in Laurel Heights?  Anyhow, the server we had was a bit forgetful first forgetting Lara's cocktail and then placing my order incorrectly.  I must have been slightly zombified since I didn't realize it until like four bites in, but then I am not a fine dining guru, that's for sure.

I ended up getting the chicken which was pretty decent.  Lara's fish was tasty and I think that was the better choice.  The starter was good as was the dessert, which was comped because of the multiple mix ups.  Portion sizes were pretty generous, but it just didn't all come together.  Maybe another time Garibaldi's...
author: Gene X.

description:
While I believe this place is worthy of 5 stars, I am just very choosy about whom I give those to, In any case If you want a great meal, service and in a cute place give Garibaldi's a chance.

Went with the BF for an early dinner on Sunday. Parking was ok, they do offer valet.

If you come before 7pm you will definitely get a table, after that you should make a reservation. There is also a small bar that we plan to sit at next time and order small plates.

They have a small but diverse menu: We had:
The  mussels in wine sauce with bacon and fries on top - VERY good. I love this dish and would order it again in a heartbeat. I thought the fries on top were an unique touch. And it was the perfect size appetizer to share.
I had the gnocchi with fennel and shallots - YUM, homemade gnocchi in a sweet, rich sauce
He had the chicken with mashed potatoes- basic but very very good and filling! He took home the extra.
We had a fantastic bottle of red wine - a French blend, I believe it was called Fleur Leiruy (?)

Service was very good, dessert menu was not very exciting. Total bill for 2 was around $100.The place is romantic inside with a large window overlooking Presido Ave. AND 2 large fruit paintings on the front wall... that look like Penis and Vagina - enjoy!

Of Fu$K it - 5 stars.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I just can't get too excited about this place, no matter how hard I try.  

I've been here twice...about a year between each visit.  Both times on the company's dime.  The restaurant is in Laurel Heights, the one neighborhood that I never ever find myself in -- so it's a bit out of the way.  And each time I go, the food is good but hardly memorable.  I tried the turkey club on foccacia bread with avacado during my last visit and it was really tasty, but it came with the parsnip soup which was horrid.  Absolutely horrid.  But maybe that was my fault for going with the soup of the day without knowing really what I was going for...  

This is definitely a place where power lunches are to be had.  The decor was fancy, the atmosphere a bit pretentious, and the service was professional but also a bit disconnected?  As if the waiters are used to being ignored by the very important people who dine there...who are obviously having very important conversations.  It's a good place to take someone to lunch if you're trying to impress them, but I definitely wouldn't go out my way to come back here, nor would I pay to eat here with my own money.
author: LaSha G.

description: The female Manager there needs to learn the meaning of customer service!  If the kitchen of a 4 star restaurant burns your entree, they should keep your date's plate warm while they refire the burned entree....AND offer an appetizer or cocktail during the extra wait.  This Mgr was annoyed and rude when the entree was returned and argued about my date watching me eat for 15 min until her new entree was prepared. This a 4 star joint with 1 star service.  Spend your $100 for two people on an Italian restaurant in North Beach and leave happy!!!
author: Freddie W.

description:
I came here for dinner with my husband on a Friday night at 7:30. We live in the neighborhood and thought it was time to try this place that's always happening. We had reservations and were seated immediately. That made me happy, especially since some reviews complain about being seated promptly. 

I LOVED the food here. They bring bread and provide an olive oil/tapenade served warm for dipping. Yum. 

We ordered from their Prix Fixe menu (bargain) and had a skirt steak, an arugula salad and dessert. We also ordered their chicken milanese which was SUPERB! Deliciously pan friend to perfection. PLUS, the serving size was huge (so you get more bang for your buck, you know?). My milanese dish had two large-sized chicken breasts served on mashed potatoes with a buttery sauce. I couldn't finish my meal. My husband couldn't finish his either. We'd have been fine ordering one or two appetizers, a salad and an entree. 

The service was impeccable. Great waiter. 

My husband's complaints: too crowded (you are literally squashed in there), too noisy, and too dim. I, on the other hand, loved the atmosphere. Hence the five star review.
author: Hilary A.

description:
This could be the least offensive restaurant in town.  Everything was delicious in an understated way.  Subdued lighting, quiet enough to talk.  All in all a very good neighborhood spot.  

UPDATE:  Garibaldi's gets the responsiveness award.  The BF complained about the cheese plate, and they changed it!!!
author: Amme P.

description:
I had lunch here (it was a business lunch) and the place was fine for a business meeting but thats the only reason i would go, i am under 40 and folks there are over 60 but thats not my main point, there were 5 in our group and we were seated in a nice round table in the corner near the bar and this huge light fixture may well have been in our food because it was so big and so low to the table you could not see other guests.  

The menu was not inspiring to say the least, my salad was bland, the sandwich dry -- again i was here for business, the staff seemed nice and all but i would not return,
author: G R.

description:
I had dinner at the bar here with some friends.  We sampled the calamari, the gnocchi, the cheeseburgers, and some croquettes.  Oh, and some drinks.  Which is why I'm not sure what was in the croquettes.....

Overall, the service was good.  My Bellini was passable, but I wouldn't get one here again.  The tequila was good.  The calamari was a bit on the salty side.  There were a variety of cheese options available, which was fabulous!
author: Nikki c.

description:
Have you ever been in a relationship where someone just LOVES something...be it a T.V. show, a band, or a movie...and to you they're just okay?  That's how it is for me with Garibaldi's.

It's the ex's joint.  He LOOOOVED it.  Considers it his haunt.  Maybe its just passive-aggression that has me going ho-hum, but the place never really got me excited.

As an occasional fish-eating vegetarian, I am always a bit disappointed with Garibaldi's.  Yet, I do enjoy their soups and (when it is actually on the menu, which is rare) the scallops with butternut squash puree and pomegranate reduction gets my heart a flutter.

So, all in all, its decent food and decent service.  Their wine list is good and the bartender makes one of my favorite Old Fashioneds in the city.  Mmmmm...Old Fashioned...Is it cocktail hour?
author: Kat P.

description:
You can tell a lot about a business by how employees react in less-that-perfect circumstances. My wife and I had tickets to attend an event at the nearby Jewish Community Center. We had made dinner plans elsewhere but traffic was terrible and we missed our reservation by a wide margin, so we just parked at the JCC and explored the neighborhood for other dinner options. 

So... we appeared at Garibaldi's at 6:15 on a Friday night, with no reservation, and the need to be done with dinner in time for a 7:30 event. The hostess seated us a bar table and assured us that we would be fine. And so we were. Our order was taken quickly, dishes arrived on time and as ordered, and the table was cleared efficiently. Based on the service, we felt as if we were in a Michelin-starred restaurant.

The food may not have been Michelin level, but it was very good. We shared the risotto croquettes and the superb chopped salad, and then each had an order of the herb-ricotta cavatelli. This turned out to be a more complex and interesting dish than I expected, with a rich flavor yet not a not a trace of oil in the bowl after finishing it. Last but not least, the  bill was 50% off since it was  happy hour. We will return for sure!
author: Tom A.

description:
I like this place. I like the food. I like the staff. I like the drinks. It's really one of the only restaurants on this side of town that never disappoints.

Yea, the clientele can be a little stuffy.  (Are you really going to sit through your whole meal with that camel hair blazer on over your starched navy and white stripe button down shirt?) But what do I care if the food is excellent, my cocktail is tasty and I don't have to trek across town for a night out with good company?
author: C. S.

description:
If a restaurant can get you to start liking seafood again. Then they deserve lots of stars for that. Haven't had seafood in about 10 years. Don't ask why. But nonetheless, any place that can make my mouth water with grilled prawns- i love it. Oh and the lemon pannecotta? AMAZING. the waiter? ADORABLE. 

Really classy, nice environment, fairly nice people- good place to go. :)
author: Lauren S.

description:
Garibaldi's is the greatest!!  I've been there several times for dinner and have never been served a meal that was less than exceptional.

Last night, my BF and I started the evening early (6pm) with some simple cocktails:  Guavacita (tequila & guava-based lowball) & French Kiss (lemon vodka & White Lillet martini).  The drinks were delicious, but I have a complaint ... they don't have an option to get them by the pitcher!   ;)

The chef seemed to have a thing for lemon (in a good way).  We chose for our antipasti the marinated white beans & olives and lemon basil hummus.  Served with crostini, both dishes were perfectly prepared.  The beans were firm and lemony and contrasted nicely with the saltiness of the calamatas.  For basil lovers, the lemon in the hummus might be a little overpowering for your tastes ... still, the microgreens were a nice touch and it worked over all.

The bacon-roasted pork tenderloin, braised red lentils, zucchini and gruyere fondutta was awesome.  Pig on pig.  How can it fail?  The lentils seemed to have a subtle white wine vinegar flavor that livened up the meatiness of the pork. 

The chicken breast Milanese, roasted garlic mashed potatoes, arugula with white wine-caper sauce is my favorite when I'm in the mood for "comfort food".  It's dressed up a bit to look appetizing: hearty enough for a lumber jack and pretty enough for a princess.

You cannot leave Garibaldi's without indulging in their Chocolate Budino.  Have you ever had an orgasm served to you in a bowl with two spoons?  I'm sure that the devil himself assembles these back there in the kitchen.  Imagine a rich chocolate pudding cake baked in a large crock, topped with hazelnut (?) ice cream & drizzled generously with hazelnut & toasted almond praline.  So effin' awesome!!

TIPS: Make a reservation through OpenTable.com and collect some points.
If you can't find a parking spot, they have valet service.
Service is more attentive earlier in the evening before the place gets jam-packed (although ... it's always adequate or better).
author: Jenny K.

description:
Walked in after a hard days afternoon of super consignment shopping and was in need of a seat at the bar and a stiff martini to ease me back into the real world.

This little gem has evaded my notice off of Sacramento Street.
I simply kept missing it for years !  
It's a lovely little place that's really elegant and comfortable.

The staff was friendly and I really liked sitting at the bar so I decided to stay and have dinner. BTW...gorgous bartender and smart and fun !

I ordered the Chicken with Mashed Potatoes. It had a perfect caper sauce and  just melted in ones mouth. Perfect comfort food.

Prices are 23-30 for entrees and very nice appetizers to try for the future.

Just perfect for the fall evenings coming up.

Very intimate, and had a sence of privacy.  Loved it

I'll definitely be back soon because I left a piece of clothing there AND when I called the next day they definitely remembered me and was holding it for me !

That's service !
author: Katherine N.

description: Upscale, pricey and classy feeling joint. Booked a romantic dinner for two on a special occasion. I checked Yelp reviews beforehand as I'm vegetarian and a previous reviewer had said that they will do a vegetarian entree, so I took the risk - wish I hadn't. The server was very rude and sniffed "Just eat a salad" at me. The hubby loved his meat, but he'll eat anything with legs. Didn't enjoy the experience here.
author: Jennie L.

description: The filet mignon was amazing. Sadly, did not have enough room in my stomach for dessert. I came here looking for a somewhat romantic birthday dinner. It was a little louder than I would have hoped but it was also somewhat busy so I guess that's to be expected. The service was excellent. Our waiter stopped by our table multiple times to check on the food and offered to call a cab for us. If you want more intimate seating, ask for the upper level seating.
author: Sabrina C.

description: We ate Thanksgiving dinner at Garibaldi's. The menu had five choices for starters, entres and desserts. The food was excellent and the meals had a flat rate of $60 a person. The filet was perfectly cooked, as was the halibut. The risotto served with the halibut was delicious. All in all, the food was a 5, but the service was slow and I would rate it a 3. I averaged the two to come up wiht a 4.
author: JeanMarie S.

description:
Aw I have a sentimental place in my heart for Garibaldi's!! It's literally right up my street so having this great find so close to home is a godsend!

It's so cozy and pretty inside.  Places like Garibaldi's are why San Francisco is one of the greatest food cities in the world.  It's a small, classy joint that has style and sophistication as well as excellent cuisine.  It's the PERFECT establishment for a romantic first date!  

I had the sea bass which was cooked to perfection, tender and full of amazing flavors!  My date enjoyed the Fillet coupled with Yukon gold potatoes.  The candlelit ambiance was relaxing and made for a perfect Saturday night dinner.  

Sometimes it's difficult to get a reservation, however finding a spot at the bar with a friend is pretty easy and really enjoyable.  Pull up a stool, grab a drink and share some appetizers!  The Frito misto and the risotto croquettes are wonderful!!!!
author: Candice M.

description:
I was thrilled to discover Garibali in SF since the one in Oakland is one of my fav restaurants.   Turned out to be a real disappointment.

I loved the scallop with black rice in Oakland and wanted it again at the SF location.  Although it was on their online menu at the time, it wasn't available at the restaurant.  I was forced to get the sole.  It was ok but much too heavy on the salt.  The chocolate buddino we had last time was excellent but at this location was also too salty!  The only dish that was scrumptious was our appy of risotto croquettes.

For this price, everything should've been flawless and it wasn't.   Nice presentation though and lovely decor.  Still, 1 dish right out of 3 just doesn't cut it. 

Won't be back.
author: Miss K.

description:
With a heavy heart and pen I must, alas, give Garibaldi's a mediocre 3 star rating.

I went to G's last Friday night with two other couples. We were looking forward to a fun night out and through a slight expense account loophole like plan, we were eating on the company dime.  Alright, it ended up being the company's Benjamin's (six of them to be exact, oops) so in light of this we had really our pick of anywhere in the city to go but we ended up here.  For the amount of money we spent, I really regret this decision now.

I was really disappointed. First of all, our service was poor and very slow. Our reservations were at 8:30 and we left at 11:30. We had several courses - cocktails, apps, salad, entree, cheese and dessert but nothing that warranted a full three hours. The waitress disappeared for long periods of time. She took our order and then returned 30 minutes later to tell us the rack of lamb was not available. She delivered this news like it was our fault. 

Our apps were blah and bland and not worth too many sentences. The griddled mancheco was the highlight, but think fancy grilled mozzarella sticks.

Salad was salad. Mine had basically no dressing on it. Is there a new minimalist movement in salads I should know about?

Entrees were good but uninspired and boring. Chicken, lamb (shanks not the rack!) and halibut were the choices all around and there was nothing exciting to rave about. Just ok.
