We had dessert but  by that point I had a bunch of cocktails in me (funny, I remember those)  and its been a few days so I can't remember what we ordered. It wasn't memorable, martinis or no martinis.

The company was fantastic and the restaurant was surprisingly lively for a Friday night in our quiet hood-o-families so that made up for the blah food.  The atmosphere is getting most of the star credit here. 

The bill showed up and I had immediate buyer's remorse and immediately had to tart figuring out how to explain a $600 tab for 6 people 2 blocks away from my house. Ugh. I'm gonna have to go talk to Joe from Accountemps about this one. 

Randomly, some nice, older Pac Heights bazilionaire type couple sent our table a round of tequila shots midway through our meal. That was the spiciest thing about the whole experience!
author: Megan L.

description:
Like many others that have reviewed Garibaldi's, we drive by it all the time taking the dog to Chrissy Field or Baker Beach and have seen the lines for the valet.  So we knew about it but hadn't had occasion to go yet.  Well they were supporting dining for life (25% of the bill for AIDS research) so we decided to go.

We went a little large again...little bit of a celebration in that I met the crew at the new job today and we are headed to Mexico for the weekend.

Started with drinks, I think we both enjoyed ours.  I had the pomegranate martini, the gf had some champagne cocktail.  Whatever, you are not going to impress me with drinks alone.

First off, we both loved the olive oil infused with something spicy.  Red pepper maybe with chunks of olives and goodness all around.  So we started to fill up on bread but then the appetizer came, meatballs.  Really tasty.  They had a bit of fennel in them so approached the Italian sausage taste, which if you read my yelps, know I am not a fan of but the flavor was not overwhelming and thus not offensive.  We ended up asking for more bread to sop up all the marinara sauce the meatballs were served in. 

We split the chopped salad which perhaps was chopped a bit more than I would like but it had bits of bleu cheese and goodness all the way through.  I dug it big time.

For entrees: gf had the filet, which had a flavor of mesquite like it was cooked on a backyard bbq.  It was served with an au gratin slab o' potatoes, which was also good.  One complaint, it was ordered medium rare and came out medium to medium well.  I may have sent it back but the gf didn't bother.

I had the lamb medium rare, it came out that way so no worries on my part.  It tasted almost Mediterraneanly spiced sitting on a bed of nicely cooked green beans and couscous.  The sauce around the plate tasted like pure butter but was amazing with everything that we dipped in it.

We didn't get dessert because I had gluttonous plans to go to Bill's Place to split a peanut butter shake.

A number of people complained about the cost of this place, my response to them: SACK UP.  We ordered an appetizer, a salad, and the two most expensive dishes and it came to $80.  Our bill was actually $120 after the cocktails and corkage.

If you want to have a nice meal in a comfortable place, give this a try.  Great mixed crowd of kids in sweatshirts to professionals dressed to the nines, nice decor, great service, in the neighborhood.  We will be back.
author: Aberdo G.

description:
Garibaldi's is located on a charming little street located in Laurel Heights. The ambiance is lovely: low lighting, nice music. 

It was date night and Jackie L recommended we try Garibaldi's. I tend to listen to her recommendations because she is yet to be wrong. 

Our waiter was helpful and very charming. We started with the risotto croquettes. mmm I'm a huge fan of risotto and have never had it in this form. I split the croquette with my folk and the cheese came oozing out.. Need I say more?

A. hates brussel sprouts-he's hated them as a kid. I've been wanting to reform him for quite some time.. with no success. The waiter promised that he would be a convert once he tried the carmelized brussel sprouts.. A. is a convert. Absolutely delightful!

The menu changes on a regular basis so the items listed below may not be available; but you're in good hands with this chef! A. ordered the lamb. Tender and perfectly cooked. I had the sole - flaky, light, nice.. 

I try to not give too many 5 stars but Garibaldi's certainly deserves it.
author: Monica S.

description:
Charming, elegant, simple. It fits perfectly within the pacific heights demographic mainly because of the high prices. But the food is interesting and experimental (try the Cauliflower Creme Brulee) 

The duck was delicious (if slightly chewy) and the Arctic Char was moist (god I hate that word) and pretty much perfect. Their veggies were all really tasty too.

I would recommend this place for a date or a small, non-rowdy group where you're willing to put down about $35 a person.
author: Ali L.

description:
This may be my new favorite restaurant!
Here's why:
- Impeccable service all around
- My mouthwatering, orgasmic scallop entree (not on the website's menu, by the way)
- Grappa for the BF
- Uniquely delicious Bellini's (made with elderflower)
- Delicious, quality wine selection, even in the less than $50 price range
- Quite enough to talk, but not uncomfortably so
- Cozy, warm, classy ambience
- A great experience overall, one that I can't stop thinking about! 
- I'll be back! :-)
author: beth l.

description: Great Happy Hour.  It's a hotspot for my parent's friends and the "It's Complicated" crowd.
author: Jack M.

description:
We arrived at 7:15pm for our reservation and the room was sparsely filled. It was a nice dimly lit room, tables were decently spaced and enough room to maneuvre in and out of your seat.

We shared the Garibaldi's salad - mixed greens, goat cheese, nectarines, spicy pecans, citrus vinaigrette which was just normal. I was suckered in by the nectarines but it was not a wow dish. Oh well, it's salad. 

For entree, bf had the Marinated Lamb Tenderloins pistachio couscous, haricot vert, tarragon sauce and I had the Yukon Gold Potato Gnocchi with sausage, broccolini, zucchini, green almonds, spring onions. I sampled bf's lamb and it was so tender and tasty and it wasn't smelly, well, it didn't have the strong lamb-y smell and it was soooooooo good! My gnocchi was decent but the lamb was definitely very flavorful! We swapped plates in the middle of the meal coz the lamb was that good! :) Hehehehe....

For dessert, we shared the Chocolate Budino - kinda like chocolate lava cake with expresso ice-cream and nuts! Was very tasty but we were so stuffed from dinner, we just had a tasting of the dessert....

As we were leaving, we noticed the crowd dining, patrons were either celebrating or were there on a romantic date...everyone was dressed up. :)
author: Yan M.

description:
I should've yelped it before I went there! Garibaldi's was on my list for italian, but I had not read the deets and thought it was "casual" italian... So we show up on a Friday evening with no reservations and wearing cargo pants and fleece... Can yelp not text my phone when it senses that I am in the neighborhood of a "grown up dressy" restaurant with three dollar signs? 
The food, the atmosphere, the service were all great. They insisted on finding us a real table even though we were totally cool with sitting at the bar (my theory is that they wanted to hide us in the back). The lamb tenderloin was so so good, and the serving sizes were pretty damn big for a "fancy" restaurrant. I got three sticks of lamb tenderloin, the guy next to me got two halves of chicken breast for his chicken etc.

So where do these people come from? Old, young, dressed in suits, most even wearing ties, women in beautiful caftans? I have been to my share of fancy restaurants in Sf and I don't remember such an old and suited clientele... And where do they go after dinner? The Opera? Or do grown-ups just go to bed after dinner? If so, I don't want to grow up... but I do want that fancy lady's caftan...
 
In summary, it was not what I had in mind for dinner, but we got to use our $15 off coupon (underdressed AND cheap), and had a great dinner.
author: Ayse B.

description:
This is actually an update / edit / rewrite  to an earlier review I submitted as well as a nod to the power of Yelp and a testament to those restaurant owners/managers who really do care about how their patrons feel about their businesses.
Suffice to say last weekend a consistently nice meal turned abruptly sour when there was a considerably embarrassing experience related to the redeeming of a Garibaldi's Gift Certificate, which had 'expired', because it had been donated. 
Despite the polite and professional delivery of the 'bad news' by our server, I Yelped quite frankly about this experience because Garibaldi's has been, for many years, a top favorite dining experience. Having had several birthday and special occasion meals there, it felt like a bitter loss to have to cross it off my list due to negative experience relating to a Gift Certificate snafu.
I was contacted by the restaurants General Manager Cate Mason [sic] via phone call within just a few days of posting my Yelp review,  and was impressed with her extremely sincere apology and overwhelming concern that our celebratory dinner had gone so badly at the end. 
There was no question for me that she was not BS'ing her way out of a bad Yelp review, I can tell some good BS'ing and it was clear she felt genuinely bad about the whole thing.
She asked if I would consider allowing her to replace the gift certificate and giving them another shot at joining them for dinner - how could anyone refuse?
Today, in the mail I received a very nice card with a sincere apology, thanking me for my insight and comments along with a new gift certificate with a value of twice the amount of the original.
This is the embodiment of  what really good business people do. Genuine concern for the perceptions of their patrons and taking the opportunity to turn around unfortunate experiences.
Will I be back to Garibaldi's - you bet
Will I recommend Garibaldi's to friends and here on Yelp - you bet.
Are the 5 stars up there in my rating section? well...there's 4 because you've always gotta leave that little bit of room for improvement, right?
It also means I'm a fan once again.

Thank You Cate and Garibaldi's - I'm happy that I can put you back on my favorite restaurant list and see you soon.
author: Andrew P.

description:
Perhaps my favorite restaurant in San Francisco?  Garibaldi's is stylish yet modest as well.  The food and service are excellent, especially if you're a party of one or two walking home from work and can sit at the bar.

Big points for:
1. Plenty of bread and marinated olives for free at the bar (not when seated)
2. A good wine list
3. Sociable and well-traveled bartenders and a lively scene at the bar most nights.
4. Of course, great food (I like the braised pork shank, chicken milanaise and the filet migon).

Cons:
1. Their limon cholo is the bitterest finish on Earth :)
author: Eric J.

description:
Seeing how I'm the king of procrastination, I didn't start looking for a place to make reservations for New Year's Eve until late this year.  This of course meant that all the trendy places or my standards were all booked solid.  Finally I came across an opening at Garibaldi's on OpenTable and decided to take a chance on them since I drive past them every day on the way to work and have often wondered if they're any good.

Our table was waiting on us as soon as we arrived (actually a few minutes early), and the staff all seemed friendly and professional.  The atmosphere is nice, lively, and skews towards an older crowd.  The place was also filled with cheesy balloons, but I'll let that slide since it was NYE.  Our pre-dinner cocktails were both well made (Manhattan for me, cosmo for her), so I'd have no complaints about coming here for a few drinks before my reservation next time. The prix fixe menu that night was actually fairly impressive and wasn't the typical NYE prix fixe menu that most places throw together for NYE because they know they'll be booked no matter what they serve.  The sweetbreads were perfectly crispy, the venison was well seasoned, perfectly cooked, as well as a fantastic cut since it wasn't gamy at all, and the dessert was very rich and tasty.  Add too this a half bottle of Merry Edwards Pinot Noir and you have a pretty nice New Years' Eve dinner.  I'll say the experience was good enough that I'll be coming back to see how their standard dinner service compares.  All in all not a bad place to take a date if you're looking for a decent meal in a slightly more relaxed environment than somewhere like Spruce.
author: Joshua W.

description: fine food, but maybe I ordered wrong as I didnt feel it was anything special.  Best part was the bread assortment served with good quality olive oil with actual olive chunks floating in it, and then the Chocolate Budino desert.  But for my main I ordered the recommended Chicken Breast Millanese and, to be honest, what I got reminded me of something you'd find at a midwest all you can eat buffet.  It was chicken, breaded and fried, on mashed potatoes with some arugula.  Tasty, sure, filling, absolutely.
author: Paul G.

description: Great place that I will definetly be going back to.  Chicken was amazing and the grilled calamari was different but very good.  If you haven't been its a must try!!!
author: Kj E.

description: The reason I am inspired to write this review is not because the food was outstanding, but rather that the hostess was brutally unwelcoming. On a rainy, Friday night one would hope a restaurant in an upscale, pricy neighborhood would at least be psyched her customers are venturing out in the weather. Instead, her eyes screamed, "Another guest? great..."  (insert sarcastic tone). In addition to the "face" of the restaurant being so off-putting, the noise level was unbearable. You could barely hear the close conversation at your own table. But what did make up for the unfortunate welcome and noise level was the nice window-side table, friendly waitress, tasty olive oil with the bread, and fantastic risotto croquettes. Hoping the weather was to blame for this experience...
author: Shannon W.

description:
The food is awesome....they really know how to put flavors together.  Everything was so fresh and beautifully made.  The portions were pretty big too....I shoudln't have eaten all of my meal, but I did beacuse it was so good.  I was really stuffed.

This is an excellent restaurant for a very nice meal.  Yes, some of the other diners are annoying when they can't stop talking loudly about their money or nice cars, but it's the neighborhood and mades for some good eavesdropping!
author: Luci B.

description:
Had lunch with some gals to celebrate a BDAY by the window. One complaint was that there were a number of black flies flying around and landing on our heads for half the time. 

Soup was yummy, as well as the sandwiches. Dressing on the salads had just a tad too much. Service was good, they filled our drinks constantly.

It's a good neighborhood spot.
author: M M.

description:
Great food and service. Probably the best service I've experienced in a long time.  Extensive wine list and fantastic cocktails.  I had the cactus blossom (tequila, lychee liqueur and grapefruit).  The tequila worked well with the lychee. My friend had the basil banger (lime gin, fresh basil, lime and pernod).  Wasnt as good as the cactus blossom, but still very refreshing.

The menu selections were terrific.  I had a hard time choosing between the three course set menu, which included moussaka, and the al a carte items.  We ended up getting an anti pasti sampler: risotto croquettes (the fontina cheese was perfectly melted inside a wonderful ball of tempura), squash blossoms and prosciutto with figs.  Absolutely yummy.  For the main course I had the day boat scallops, served with truffled risotto cakes, pioppini mushrooms and a fennel salad.  Holy crap was it good!  My friend had the lamb tenderloins, served with pistachio couscous, haricot vert and a tarragon sauce, which was amazing.  We didnt want to leave.  The warm chocolate cake with coffee ice cream dessert was a little disappointing.  It was good, but not fantastic.  I would probably try something else next time I go.
author: brewgirl b.

description:
This is one of my top 5 restaurants in San Francisco -- which is a strong statement given the extensive selection this city has to offer. I love their brussel sprout appetizer and for the main course I always get either the chicken milanese with mashed potatoes or the lamb with couscous (ideally, get one myself and "encourage" my date to get the other). Both dishes are cooked to perfection and their respective sides match perfectly.

Pardon the interview response cliche, but one of their greatest strengths is also one of their only weaknesses: consistency. I love the fact that the menu is small and I can get the same thing every time, but I hate the fact that the menu is small and I don't have to leave my comfort zone. Would be nice to see more frequent specials or perhaps seasonal variations.
author: Patrick D.

description:
After Spruce's staff nearly laughed us out of the restaurant for trying to "walk-in", we headed here for drinks/dinner on a random, impromptu Friday night. We were quickly accommodated although the restaurant was bustling. Our waiter was amazing - a true gem. He joked with us and gave us excellent service.

on a side note - I love their Manhattan's (it's the brandied cherries that I really love). Not only did the waiter bring me extras but, when I was trying to recreate them for a dinner party and I called the restaurant, they gladly gave over the secret recipe & supplier. That's excellent customer service!

ps - as a city-dweller, I did not even know this was a chain and have never gotten the impression dining here that it would be such a thing ;-)
author: C'est La V.

description: I used to work very close to this place and went there quite often!  They have lunch program, which provides their lunch cheaper than actually eating in and they have also stamp card for it  Their chicken sandwich is amazing. It has grilled apple inside and it is so yummy. I really miss this place ever since I moved out of San Francisco. I highly recommend this place!
author: M N.

description:
Lovely ambiance and fantastic yummy food with great service.

The bruschetta app was delicious with plentiful mozzarella yumminess. The turkey club had a tasteful delight of  spread that added interest and the bacon was done just perfect to add. I had a moroccan carrot soup that tasted outta this country with flavor! :)

Even saw and spoke with the executive chef for a few minutes! John, i think his name is.. so creative. Recommended a new dessert to try...  it was an array of gelato paired perfectly with accent pieces of crumbles. Wish I would have taken a pint home...

I was visiting with a dear friend and wouldn't have rathered anything different. We were there for several hours as the wait staff graciously accommodated.
author: Jvb B.

description: Who knew? Lived in the neighborhood for years before trying it. The food was fantastic. Honestly one of the best meals I had in SF maybe all year.
author: Nick L.

description: I was highly underwhelmed. I wanted to like it and was with nice company and all, but I thought the food was very disappointing. And certainly not cheap. Their fritto misto was quite awful really, overly done and should never have left the kitchen. The chopped salad was fine, but nothing really to write home about. I expected much more.
author: Violet A.

description: The menu is very seasonal. I had the wild boar bucatini pasta dish and the tart cherries and the brussel sprouts in it really enhanced the flavor. My dining companion had the maple-brined pork chops and they were super flavorful!  Good service too.
author: SF O.

description:
Oh Dahling your restaurant is fancy schmancy. Since I am a regular folk, I dined with you for your Dine about Town special, and felt quite snubbed for it. Althought you consider yourself five stars, I beg to differ.....

Honestly the pork loin that was served, tasted like caffeteria food. I wished I could have sent it back-but yet again what would be my other option? Oh yes, the tasteless chicken they served to my friend. I could whip up something better then that. The sauce was very runny and bland. The starter salad was also funky with an ill smelling dressing. The only thing that was decent was the dessert and wine, but how hard is it to screw that up?

I would not go back, hmph!
author: Heather S.

description:
Looking for good food and value in Pacific Heights?   Try Garibaldi's, a sleek, almost swank neighborhood place on Presidio Avenue.   It seems to be a go-to place for a somewhat older set, but you will find a few younger couples there as well.  Regardless of age, you get an enthusiastic welcome and soon thereafter some good bread accompanied by olives and olive oil  

I go for the prix fixe dinner.  An incredible bargain for under $25.  A salad of mixed greens, walnuts, persimmon, and crumbled cheese is a welcome way to start a meal.

It's been so long since I've had fried chicken.  The chicken here is properly fried, not at all greasy, and moist within.  It's accompanied by mashed potatoes and brocolli florets.  Comfort food. 

Dessert is a chocolate budino accompanied by ice cream and walnuts.  It has an off taste and is the weakest part of a very nice meal.  

Service was a bit intrusive, even cloying, but enthusiastic.  Garibaldi's tries hard to please and largely succeeds.
author: David D.

description:
I came here for my birthday and I have to say that it was definitely a great experience. The ambience is perfect for an intimate (okay, okay, slightly intimate) dinner with a small group of friends. 

Cocktails (and I rarely drink) = A; dangerously good
Appetizers = interesting and tasty
Entrees = simply delicious (and I polished off my plate)

Dessert was the best; they were even so kind as to have written "Happy Birthday Mary" in chocolate along the edges of my plate. Isn't that so sweet? I know it made me feel very good!

Ah, and our waiter was a darling. Not only was he attentive and helpful, he also had some personality too! I love when the waiter provides flawless service while making it look easy; he was a natural. Too bad I can't remember his name! :(
author: Mary L.

description:
omgod. 
the pan fried buttermilk fried chicken sandwich is the best sandwich ive had all year. 
try the drinks too. 

amazing service. fancy. dress up! make a reservation too!

i am so glad they let me do take outs. thanks!
author: Veranna N.

description:
Took my mom here for Mother's Day and it was perfect.  Excellent food, great service.  Highly recommend the Chicken that is lighlty breaded and flash fried (can't remember the name).  I didn't order it, but mom shared.  (of course she did, that's what mom's do!)  Ravioli was great, but if you have any kind of appetite, you better get the full portion, I ordered half and it was 2 ravioli's (hence the sharing with my mom).
Strawberry Rhubarb tart amazing.  So were the drinks, I ordered a "Salty Dog." Yum.  Maybe the small portion was good after all, I still had room for dessert...
author: Andrea R.

description:
Very nice restaurant. We came in on a wednesday night, and had no problem getting a table for two. Nice decor, and very attentive service. I felt like I was a little underdressed for the place, but the staff and the general ambience was laid back enough that I didn't feel like a total slob. and the lamb dish that I had was absolutely excellent. I'd definitely recommend it.

Also, I thought that the limoncello that they served after the meal was very good. But I'll drink anything, so who knows.

The dessert menu could have been a little bit better, though, which prevented this from being 5 stars.
author: Edward C.

description:
We came here with another couple for dinner on a weeknight.  I think this time I will give this place five stars since I really can't find anything wrong with it - other than it's pricier than we'd like - but we know that already so it's not a "fault" that warrants any minuses.  And plus, it's not a place we would dine at all the time anyway, so once in a while a little splurge is worth it.  

The couple we came here with dines here all the time.  We had three salads (one a large one to share); three sole entrees; and I had the linguini with seafood (again).  We only had one dessert - chocolate budino.  My linguini was superb, just absolutely delicious.  Big pieces of prawns and lots of other seafood.  I can't stop thinking about it.

Bill came to just under $200 including tax and tip for four people who ordered three salads, four entrees, and one dessert.  

I was impressed that by the time we left at 8 PM, the restaurant was full!  On a weeknight, too. 

That night my water broke and I delivered the next day.  So in essence, I have to give this place five stars.  Am I glad I had my last supper here instead of some unspectacular frozen fish or can of chili at home.

We will be back for more special occasions and following my trend, I'll be ordering linguini with some sort of seafood.  Next time, alcohol will definitely be drunken.
author: Mrs F.

description: very tasty food with great balance between protein, veggie... and flavors.
author: Abraham Y.

description:
Simply put, Garibaldi is an excellent choice for a high quality meal in Presidio Heights with appropriate prices, attentive and knowledgeable service, and romantic setting. My filet with chantarelles was perfectly cooked and delicious, and heirloom tomato caprese amazing! I was also delighted (as a beer geek) to see that they had Delirium Tremens on the list, an indicator in my mind of some forethought and knowledge on the part of those responsible for writing the menu.

Garibaldi is an excellent restaurant that I could quite possibly award five stars, and hope to visit once again in the near future. Excellent.
author: Aaron J.

description:
Great location near the Presidio.   I went there for lunch and had the chicken sandwich.  It was perfect.  

Luv the setting and ambience.
author: Raider J.

description: This was the most exquisite dining experience I've had in the City.  The new chef has more than a few tricks up his sleeve.  The pork watermelon starter brought tears of joy it was so delectable.  If I ever need to impress a date, or my parents,  I'm bringing them to Garibaldi's.
author: Captain J.

description:
I love this restaurant!  It's a great neighbourhod gem.  The atmosphere is cozy and the food is great.  You must try the lamb - it is SO good.

It's a little pricey, but worth the splurge every now and then.
author: Angela L.

description: We got reservations at Garibaidi's last minute and didn't know what to expect since we rarely dine out in San Francisco. The service was great and the food was delicious. Would definitely recommend and we will definitely go back!
author: Adena A.

description: The food is fantastic, staff is great, but it is very loud so be prepared to yell your conversations! Also, we had 8:30 reservations and didn't get seated until 9 PM...not too bad I guess
author: M s.

description:
I was very disappointed with our visit to Garibaldi's.  I was told how incredible this restaurant is and I was looking forward to it.  Unfortunately I won't be going back.

The restaurant's is long and narrow with the second half up a short flight of steps.  The front half has dining on the left and a bar area on the right, each separated by a glass half partition.  The decor was boring and uninspiring.

I went to the men's room when we first arrived and encountered the smallest sink I think I've ever seen at a restaurant.  It was square and measured maybe 10" x 10".  It was so small that the pipes (complete with tape wrapped around them) caught my eye more than the sink.  My next concern was that I was going to splash water all over myself with such a small sink.  And right next to the sink was a paper half towel dispenser.  The same kind you can find in any chain restaurant.  There is zero decor in the men's restroom and seemed to be completely forgotten in regards to the dining experience.   

Right after we got there someone ordered a desert that had two cinnamon sticks sticking out of it.  They were lit on fire and smoldering, and when they went past there was the smell of smoke with an aroma of burned cinnamon.  I've never seen this before and was at first intrigued by the artistry and uniqueness of the desert.  When the cinnamon was blown out it left a hideous aroma of burned cinnamon that went quickly from interesting to obnoxious.  Someone ordered another of these deserts and the aroma was now terrible.  I have no idea if this is a signature of Garibaldi's or an experiment but I understand now why I've never seen it anywhere before.  It doesn't work.

For appetizers we ordered buratta, calamari, and steak tar-tar.  The presentation on the steak tar-tar was nice but there was too much steak and it was boring in taste.  The calamari was excellent and the only highlight of the meal.  The calamari was not breaded and it might have been grilled, I don't remember.  It was wonderful.  The buratta was a huge disappointment.  It came with four pieces of overly toasted bread, two of which were burned that we didn't need replaced, and each piece was about one inch thick.  And there was only about two or three tablespoons of buratta and there was no taste whatsoever in the buratta.  The bread was dry and large there wasn't enough buratta to do anything about it.  The buratta at A16 is incredible and I a hoped that Garibaldi's might be similar, but no.

For entrée's we had the chicken and the salmon.  The salmon was not cooked and we sent it back.  We were too disappointed with everything to have it replaced.  The chicken was breaded breast over arugula and mashed potatoes with some sort of caper sauce.  There was no presentation with the chicken; just two huge pieces of chicken layered on top of each other on top of mashed potatoes with arugula on the side.  Thought the chicken was cooked well the breading wasn't seasoned and the entre wasn't pleasurable to eat, more like a chore.

The only time we eat sweets is to order desert and pair it.  There were about five choices of deserts and each was ice cream based.  No thanks.

Though the patrons there seemed to be having a good time I wonder if their experience was similar to ours or we just caught Garibaldi's on a bad night.  Either way  we won't be going back.
author: Kevin P.

description: Usually one of our favorite local gems and a place I'd call 4-star but today the service was 'meh'. Maybe because we went too early, but we got our salads before wine, offered bread/olives AFTER we finished our dinner. At least the food was still high quality! Also wished they offered dark linens or at least ones that wouldn't leave lint all over my dark jeans.
author: Jen K.

description:
This place was great! I went here last week with my roommates and my little brother, and I think it was a wonderful choice.  We started off with drinks, which we were hoping to get from the HH menu, but once we were seated, our waitress informed us that we would all have to fit in the tiny walk way near the tiny bar in order to order from the HH menu. We decided that it was too much of a hassle. 

I started with a glass of Pinot Noir. Although on the pricey side (all of the drinks were very pricey), it was enjoyable and it was as if they had just corked the bottle for me. Three of us, myself included, had the pre fixe menu, which consisted of an iceberg salad, pork, and white chocolate dessert. I was not blown away by the food, but it was different and tasty enough that I do remember the taste. The pork was tender, and not overcooked at all.

All in all, I will go back here again for a cozy dinner, being it near my house!
author: Chieko H.

description: Went there last nite for happy hour w/some former co-workers/friends.  When we arrived @ 5, the place was empty (yah for us).  Since our table wasn't ready til 5:30, we had drinks at the bar.  I'm a real lightweight so I'm a bit leery of cocktails.  My house white wine was perfect!  Got that very light buzz I can stand.  On the flip side, the happy hour is not really "happy," in that the prices are not reduced and you can only get the happy hour small plates at the bar.  Speaking of small, they pack 'em in here--by the time we left, we had to literally squeeze past everyone to get out.  However, the papas, risotto balls, and house salad were fabulous; the perfect portion size for me.  Delicious and made me curious about the entrees for next time.  If anyone was at Garibaldi's last nite, I am so sorry for the over-the-top person in our party.  She'd had a hard week at work and was ready to let loose, in spite of the classy atmosphere.  Now that we know, we've got a dive bar in our sights the next time we get together.  Thanks to the gracious staff for not kicking us out. ;)
author: Ressie W.

description: Hands down my favorite neighborhood fine dining establishment, but I'll admit I'm a regular. Kate and Ingred run the front desk with aplomb, while Christian and Jay expertly mix a wide variety of classic and specialty cocktails.  The food is fresh and delicious and the service is prompt.  Try the burrata appetizer and the sea bass on quinoa pilaf, or just a burger...one of the best in town.
author: Adam M.

description: Why aren't there NEGATIVE stars? This restaurant sucks!  We live down the street and can only do takeout.  First time, they take our order once it opens but it isn't ready for 2 hours (whoopsie is the only excuse given). Major attitude when I brought up how late our food was.  Tonight, I thought I'd give it another try b/c I do like the pate.  We spent a couple $$$hundred in takeout for a special dinner and again they effed up the order - left out the pates.  Excuse given: "well, that's life!"  Ummm wow!  Then Andy calls me back (after probably realizing what he was thinking was said aloud) and says he'd like to make it up to us, yada-yada.  So many more options - Goodbye Forever, Garibaldi's!  Here are other great options in our neighborhood with better food and more exceptional service:  SPRUCE and OSTERIA.  Stay away from this restaurant!
author: Bellsey B.

description: Great place. We went on the spur of the moment and were delighted by imaginative dishes and drinks. Excellent choice and the prix fixe is a great deal: 3 courses for $29.
author: Bernice C.

description:
I would like to personally thank Garibaldi for feeding me with one of the better lunches I've had in a while!  The garlic roasted white bean puree was the type of soup dreams are made of, no joke.

Their club sandwich was so fresh I could not describe it in any way other than divine!  The side of greens was dressed in the most delicious blend of lemon and olive oil, just right.  I got take out but having seen the restaurant  interior I know I will be returning REALLY soon for some in house dining.
author: Catrinel A.

description:
GREAT FOOD, TERRIBLE SERVICE! 

What's a girl to do? Maybe the best thing is to eat by yourself at the bar so that an employee is within punching distance. 

For my beautiful friend's birthday dinner, we all piled into Garibaldi's and were sad to get stuffed in the back room where it was stuffy. As the festivities heated up, so did the temperature.

I pined for ice, and realized it was a lost cause because of the ten of us, about four people's entrees had been cleared from in front of them while the rest of us stared at our empty plates (cuz the food was delicious!) in dismay with nary a waiter nor busperson in sight. 

HELLO? 

It was like pulling teeth to get the bill, ICE, a dessert menu, new bottles of wine...

And when we left (after 4 hours!! HELLO!) we were shocked to feel the twenty degree temperature difference between the oven of the backroom and the pleasant breeze with ceiling fans of the front room.

Do they do take out? Delivery? Because I'm not sure I will ever set foot in there for a meal wherein I would have to rely on the absentee employees. 

Bummer. Maybe the chef will take up somewheres else!
author: Stephanie B.

description:
I had drinks and appetizers here last night. 

So. 

Delicious. 

The croquettes were to die for, and the papas were equally delish! The executive chef John is super friendly and is very creative in his dishes. 

Dessert: freshly made vanilla icecream (OMG) and a peanut semifreddo (I think that's what it was called) that was reminiscent of the childhood favorite, ants-on-a-log. SO GOOD!!!! 

Would highly recommend this place for yummy appetizers.
author: Madoolsy W.

description:
I've been coming here since the late 80s. I know, I'm dating myself.
It's always been nothing but fabulous. It's a hidden neighborhood location. You may  easily walk right by it.

They had a Garibaldi's pasta dish to die for, back in the 80s.

I have yet to have anything I didn't like. You can impress your date by posing as the Presidio Heights cognoscenti.
author: Pandora B.

description: Very delicious! All of the dishes are tasty; the burger especially. It's cozy and romantic. The staff is always very professional and friendly.
author: C C.

description: There is something to be said about these OG spots. Had lunch on their friends & family special (give a secret word for a great discount) and would have said it was a good deal at full price. Pork tenderloin was amazing. We were very early, so it was nearly empty (filling up as we left), so we got plenty of attention.
author: Robert M.

description:
Me: Sea bass.....the best sea bass i have ever had
Wife: Lamb.....she loved it

Nice "mini" desserts, which hit the spot without the guilt
Nice ambiance/decor.....walked in and got lucky with a spot at the bar, because otherwise pretty jam packed.  

Really impressed.
author: Troy L.

description:
i guess you should arrive on time for your reservation.  i figured this was an out-of-the-way bistro that would be half-filled on a thursday but who knew!?  who knew that the corner of Sac and Presidio would be THE spot to be on thursday.  well, i'm exaggerating but yo, it is a bit crowded.  i was a bit late and conceivably we could have lost our table but the gods were with us that night and we managed to sit.  

food was predictably (given the bustlingness of the place) much better than i figured it would be.  the salmon came pre-split - since the gf is a mongo 95 pounds, we split entrees.  and the salmon was super tastey.  the blood orange salad and the meatballs were excellent starters to split also.  my chardonney was minerally.  the profiteroles, which i was specifically instructed NOT to pronounce with an Italian flair... were tops.  i think you should really pronounce them like your italian.... like you're in the Godfather or something : PROE-FEE-TAY-ROLL-AYS!!!!  geev-a-mee-a da PROE-FEET-TAY-ROLL-AYS!

excellente.  and i like the valet parking too since parking isn't super easy.  you can probably find it yourself.  just not when you're so late that you might lose your table!
author: dan h.

description:
My boyfriend made a reservation here this week and it was so delicious. Really enjoyed the food and service. 

By far some of the best lamb I have ever had, flavors were great. The service was great, the tables are little closer together then I like them but it was nice interior inside. The salmon dish was also very good but, I am giving it 4 stars on the lamb dish itself. 

Corkage fee is $20 - yikes people! 

Will likely be back again....:)
author: Kristina A.

description:
As a last minute dinner venue change, my coworkers and I did not know of Garibaldi's. 

Many reviewers have noted the restaurant to be really fancy and stuffy. I wouldn't quite call it to all that extreme... I've been to really "fancy schmancy" places, where it is stuffy and quite uncomfortable. I would describe it as where you would want to be aware of your manners, as you should anywhere else. 

The service we received was quite welcoming and sincere from us walking in to saying our goodbye. The food is very good and well presented. But I don't think there's anything on the menu were I would consider to make Garibaldi unique amongst other SF restaurants. 

I had the chicken breast milanese. To me, the dish is a pretty big portion but I am not complaining. The chicken was lightly breaded and cooked perfectly to match the mash potatoes and the arugula. Which I wouldn't mind having more of the arugula. 

My coworkers had ordered the linguine and the scallops. Both plates looked very tasty to where I would like to go back to try those dishes. Overall the meals were very good and priced at what you would get back. 

Enjoy.
author: Long T.

description:
The ambiance is really nice and romantic although it makes one feel a bit claustrophobic due to the tight spacing between tables and chairs.

The food is pretty good. I really liked their pork dish (can't remember the name) which was equivalent to Buckeye's skirt steak in style but since that one time I had it, they no longer do.

Service was nice but not exceptional.
author: Mashimaro M.

description:
My siblings and I decided to take my parent's to Garibaldi's for their birthday. Yes, my parents share the same birthday, very odd. This place was perfect for a family dinner. The atmosphere is quiet, intimate and very classy. The service was excellent and very attentive.

The menu was very "Californian Traditional." You could find your basic chicken, beef, and fish offerings. Nothing on the menu was that exciting. Honestly, it sounded very boring. 

Since I had a pretty late lunch, I wasn't too hungry and ended up ordering two small plates. I started with the salmon tartare with creme fraiche and crispy toast. It was good, but not outstanding. Then I had the chopped salad with chicken. The salad was mixed with greens, broccoli, cauliflower, pumpkin seeds and blue cheese. Nice combination of veggies. 

As the entrees came, I would have to say the lamb cutlets were the highlight. The 3 juicy, tender cutlets were served over couscous. My parents both had the short ribs and they were tender and moist. My brother in law had the sole, which was prepared very nicely in taste and texture. Overall, the food was good.

For dessert, we shared the spice cake with creme fraiche, which was quite disappointing. The cake was not moist. After one taste, you can tell it was pre-made and kept in the fridge for a while. 

I'm glad I finally got the chance to dine at Garibaldi's, but I probably wouldn't make this place a destination.
author: Denise L.

description:
3.5 stars.  Nice neighborhood place, but I'm not sure I'd drive across town for it.  
I LOVE the fact that its not too noisy.  The drinks are yummy and I've never had a bad dish.  Last time I was there, I had the Garibaldi Salad (wonderful), and the mushroom gnocchi, which was surprisingly light. My friend was insistent on french fries, which weren't bad, but I would have liked them a lot thinner and crispier.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
I've been here twice, once for dinner and once for brunch.  5 stars for the dinner experience and 3 stars for the brunch experience = average of 4.

Service and food at dinner were both excellent (I had their seafood pasta, my bf had their specialty chicken dish which was very tasty).  Our server was so nice and answered many of our questions with a very friendly response, not the I-have-another-table-to-get-to response.  She even comp'd us glasses of Muscat for dessert.

Brunch, on the other hand, was a less than satisfying experience, unfortunately.  Food was very good, but service was very bad.  This time, I was part of a party of six, which just also happens to be when they chip in the automatic gratuity.  Coincidence?  I hope so.

Although we were seated right away, it took about 30 minutes to have our order taken.  Then, it took another 45 mins or so to get our food, even though 4 of us ordered the exact same thing!!  However, once we did have our food it was so good that the wait was forgotten.  I just wouldn't come in for brunch unless you had 2 hrs to spare.
author: Ennie D.

description:
Ok-a place that finally gets it right., good food, nice modern ambiance and waitstaff that doesn't  rush you (even if its way past closing time, and you're half an hour past being the last couple in the place).

The food- the lamb. oh yes, the lamb- its the best i've ever had- better than in Morocco, anywhere in france and yes, here in SF- get it, it'll change your view on life (or at least, about lamb). The chicken milanese is super yum..

And the fries are awesome- perfectly crunchy on the outside, and nummy on the inside....

the downsides- a little noisy and sometimes it gets warm in there...so minus a half-star,...but its still fab-u-lous....eat here now!
author: Tim V.

description:
One of the best restaurants in the Presidio/Laurel Heights area. Best place to go if you're craving a burger with fries at lunch in a beautiful atmosphere. The burgers are awesome and the fries are the best around!! The service is up to par as well. 

I will be back to try the dinner menu.....
author: La C.

description:
Boss treated me to lunch here and I must say it's pretty solid.  I started with a broth-based pureed mushroom soup that was really really good.  I could've had another order of it and been satisfied!  That was followed with a pan roasted halibut w/ interesting veggies:  some kind of pureed olive tapenade, pureed peas or peashoots and pureed carrots.  I was hoping for veggies with some substance vs. babyfood but all-in-all it was still very tasty.  Did I want dessert?  Of course!  But I couldn't exactly bring myself to do it for fear the boss wouldn't have been too pleased since she passed on it herself.  Shucks...

It's a pretty sedate dining room so not a place for fun but good for business meals.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
Having Garibaldi's in our neighborhood is a real treat.  We just dined there last night and it was, as always, fantastic!  Our waiter was outstanding.  The menu is versatile, and provides so many lovely options, it is hard to make a decision.  Desserts are spectacular.

I highly recommend the Garibaldi salad - i crave it and can't seem to start with anything else now.  The braised short rib was tender and tasty.  My husband did a wine pairing with his meal and was delighted at the selection and divine pairing.  I have no meal regrets and always recommend this fab neighborhood spot to friends and visitors.
author: Lee B.

description:
I liked it a lot.  4 for the food, 5 for service, making it 4.5 stars.

Located in the perfect neighborhood (if Presidio Heights wasn't so damn far from 280, I would have lived up here), hidden away on a cute street, the restaurant has a warm ambience and simple decor.

I had their seasonal pre-fixe, and my husband had a citrus salad and gnocchi.  My pre-fixe was a bagna cauda (I didn't think I would stumble on this in the US, it is fresh vegetables with olive oil and anchovies) and mushroom risotto.  The meal was delicious.  I had a taste of my husband's citrus salad too, and it was heavenly.

The best thing though, about this place, is the service.  Our server was super nice and very accomodating, for example, my husband changed his salad order (from Garibaldi to Citrus) 3 min after the server had taken the order.  But he did not say that he couldn't change it, he rushed immediately to the kitchen to change it!  So nice.  There were many other things where he was flexible and tried his best to make the most out of our evening.  Just for him, we will be back.

Great for date nights or cozy birthday dinners.
author: Yu T.

description:
Can you say "DOUBLE DATE"? If the lamb was not amazing i would have probably been uncomfortable. If the whole meal was not amazing I probably would have not walked to the Lions Den afterwards. 

This place is hot like the Marina does not even know!
author: Bryan M.

description:
When we walked in, Neil said something like, "This looks like the kind of San Francisco restaurant that you see in the movies."  That just warmed the cockles of my heart and set the tone for a blissful meal with friends.

Garibaldi's has an easy warmth about it, while it exudes quality and sophistication.  It's the kind of restaurant I would definitely frequent if I lived a bit closer.  You know, because I'm so sophisticated, yet warm.

Coming from SoMa, I drove and found parking easily.  But you know how it is; if you drive, you allow yourself only one drink, if any at all.  And I'm not one to feel guilty over my preference to have bounties of wine with a nice meal.  So this time I was stuck with just one drink, but next time it's someone else's turn to drive.

There were five of us, which makes trying several selections easy.  To start, we had a nicely dressed Caprese salad (with bufala mozzarella, my fav), a watermelon/olive salad (interesting, fun), meatball soup (packed some heat w/whole chili peppers in the soup), crostini with delish spread and fried balls of wonder (that's not the name; I just can't recall whether they were mozzarella or what).  Oh--and green beans with pancetta, which fulfilled both my bacon and veggie quotas for the day. Everything we shared for the first course was solid.

After endless recommendations to try the lamb, that's what I chose for my main course.  A-m-a-z-i-n-g.  Just get it.  And get it rare.  Mmmmm.

For dessert, we shared 3 dishes:  a pine nut tart (their version of a pecan pie), a raspberry crumble and an amazing caramel brownie sundae.  I recommend the pine nut tart and the sundae--both really good.

The service was impeccable, the food perfect and the ambiance inviting.  I highly recommend going on a date or as a group.  And remember to order the lamb!
author: Em P.

description: Garibaldi's is a wonderful neighborhood restaurant. It has good food, seamless service and a lovely ambiance.
author: Lindsay M.

description: Great food, great service, great cocktails !  We stopped in and had a great experience for dinner.  The chicken breast Milanese with mashed potatoes was tender, very flavorful and very satisfying.  We also had margaritas and I have to say that they were some of the best I've every had, comparable or better than I've had in some high end  tequila bars.  To sum it up.  High end experience without the price or pretense. We will become regulars.
author: Charles D.

description: I had my birthday dinner here. A great meal, follow everyone else's suggestion and get the lamb. Dessert was a chocolate budino and a hot toddy; both were amazing, but the hot toddy was like nothing I've ever had before. I'd go back just to get it. Ingrid, the manager that night was courteous and friendly, Lauren, our hostess was efficient and well-versed in the menu, and Adam, our waiter, was one of the best waiters I've had in recent memory: prompt, honest, and good at understanding and presenting your meal exactly the way you want. I could not recommend it more strongly.
author: Chris N.

description:
We went here for the OpenTable Dine About Town promo.  Pretty damn decent.  The wine pairing bordered on exceptional.  The food was impeccably prepared.  The decor is speakeasy meets modern convention.  The only knock on the restaurant for me is the table arrangement which, depending on your seat, can put you next to the loud ignoramus who is intent on speaking so loudly that you feel intimately acquainted with he and his botox-injected trophy wife by the end of the evening (miss you already, Tim).

Otherwise, everything within the restaurant's control is managed to perfection.  We shall return.
author: Patrick W.

description:
YES, YES and YES!

Garibaldi's has got it down!  

Great upscale atmosphere....  warm, inviting and perfectly lit.   The Peligreeno was ice cold and they made perfect Gin(Hendricks) and tonics.   Ordered the asparagus (which was prepared perfectly) and the Filet.  I have to say one of the best filet's I've had.  Service was outstanding and so was the fruit crisp for dessert.  Everything was spot on.    5 stars!!  OUTSTANDING!! 

G
author: Piper C.

description:
The menu changes monthly and I always seem to find something to like.  They have an interesting twist to staple Continental cuisine.  Ginger infused risotto, cauliflower creme brulee, and pork tenderloin with some yummy cheese and bacon on it.  The desserts always look good too.

The portions are a good size here.  No walking away thinking you just ate the most expensive appetizer ever.

It's expensive and the crowd is a cosmopolitan mix between Presidio Heights' old money and its nouveau riche, but for something in the neighborhood on special occasions it's fun.

Also,  there is a big difference between the lunch and dinner menus.
author: Rob U.

description:
I'm totally not a lamb fan, but at Garibaldi's I will always recommend my date get the lamb...just so I can have a taste.

The environment here is pretty formal, but through some architectural/accoustical feat I manage to never hear what my neighbors are saying...or maybe I have been fortunate to have such intriguing company that I haven't noticed what my neighbors were saying.  A couple glasses of wine and the conversation turns naughty and the food arrives just in time before any real trouble begins.   

The wait staff is super friendly and always, please, always take their recommendation - they won't steer you wrong.    I've never managed to need a dessert at the end of the meal, but they look delicious.
author: Maria C.

description:
Now, I normally don't venture out to this hood, seeing as how I'm NOT over 60, nor am I balding.  However, considering the stuffiness of the place I will most certainly come back (which is a feat unto its own).

The several occasions in which I have been have allowed me to try a significant portion of the dishes they have to offer.  But what really has me coming back is their lamb tenderloin.  Grilled to perfection on the outside and tender on the inside, this Mediterranean-rubbed piece o' meaty goodness is totally fan-friggin-tastic!  Another entree worth gushing about is their pasta.  Seasonal raviolis, agnolottis or whatever.... mmm.... fresh pasta!

Good wine list.  Service is attentive and unobtrusive.  Bartender is cute.  All in all, solid food for a foodie.  Just be sure to make your man wear his bow tie and blazer to dinner.  =)
author: Adrian L.

description:
Service was excellent. We didn't have reservations but the hostess suggested we try waiting for a seat at the bar. 15 minutes later a couple of seats at the bar opened up and we sat down and ordered some drinks. The bartender was a little bit perplexed that my date ordered a fruity drink, and kept asking us whether he made the right drink, and we had to keep assuring him that he did. I was a bit disappointed to realize that they only serve appetizers and drinks at the bar, so we asked the hostess to let us know when a seat became open in the dining room. 15 minutes later a seat opened up and we sat in the little backroom which was a lot less noisy than the front room.

The crowd in the room was definitely older, and there seemed to be a lot of couples, gay to straight. It was fun to people watch.

As our entree, we ordered the seabass and filet mignon. The food was excellent, both the fish and filet were cooked to perfection. We ordered desserts, duo sorbets and chocolate budino. I couldn't finish the budino on my own, but it was delicious. Basically tasted like strong espresso ice cream on top of flourless chocolate cake. The sorbet was definitely homemade as I tasted pieces of the green apple (more like sour applie) and mango (could've been another fruit, I forget). It was good if you like sorbet.

After they took our desserts away, they handed us a neon shot of something. I took a sip and it tasted like a really strong lemon drop. I don't know about you, but I don't normally take vodka shots right after a full meal, so I had to deduct points for that call. sorry.

Overall, the food was excellent, just pass on the neon alcoholic shot at the end. :)
author: cynthia b.

description:
I knew parking would be difficult, but magically a spot opened up right in front. Wow!  Walked in and our table for seven was ready. Nice. 

Cucumber Martini...it's just so perfect w/ the super fresh olive bread and tapenade dip. 

Next was the fritto misto w/ pimenton aioli which we couldn't stop eating. Yummy cubes of eggplant, snap peas, squash, onions, lemons & calamari fried to perfection!   Also loved the chopped salad w/ fava beans, English peas with buttermilk dressing. Simply delcious!

The main course of couse: The Chicken Breast Milanese was heavenly. Impressively moist, golden, panko crusted  breast and tenderloin served on creamy  garlic mash, arugula and lemon caper sauce. Again, perfectly executed!  My husband had the steamed halibut  with salsa verde which was very good, but not memorable compared to The Chicken Milanese. 

We shared the chocolate budino w/ espresso gelato, caramel sauce and caremelized hazelnuts.  Excellent contrast of temperatures and textures. Perfectly composed dessert!  Bravo to the pastry chef. What a great ending.  

Garibaldi's exceeded our expectations.  Unpretentious, seriously well executed dishes and great service.  What's not to like? 
Incredibly fresh, simple and familiar food prepared expertly.....Now that's what I'm talking about!
author: Jane F.

description:
I've been here twice recently for two different experiences and both were great.  

First, I went for a formal dinner with friends.  The menu is extremely inviting and flexible.  They pretty much have something for all tastes.  The service is on-point and didn't miss a step all night.  It is a predominately italian-inspired menu but there are many other flavors to be had.  The lamb is well spoken for in these reviews and certainly lives up to expectations.  Their filet is top-notch.  I ordered pan seared salmon which was expertly cooked.  There are certain kitchens in this city that just know how to cook fish and this is one of them.  

My second time here was for a small dinner at the bar for happy hour.  One my first visit I was impressed with the service in the dining room and I must say the bartenders certainly take care of their customers just as well.  The cocktails are perfectly balanced and the dinner was just as good as I had remembered.  The happy hour is a great deal with half priced wines, cocktails and appetizers.  

Overall, two really great experiences.  I'd give it 10 stars if I could, 5 stars for each visit.
author: henry c.

description:
My first experience with Garibaldi's was actually at Garibaldi's on College in Oakland.  I was always pleased with the food, service and ambience there and I found it to be appropriate for business and social gatherings.  

After moving to "this" side of the Bay, we have become loyal fans of Garibaldi's on Presidio.  The caliber of food and service at this location is on the same level as we were accustomed to at the College Ave. location.  The one PLUS is that this location seems to bring in many more "locals" which makes the restaurant feel more cozy and inviting. 

We have since returned at least once a year, and usually to celebrate a special occasion and we have never been disappointed.  I would recommend their asparagus with pancetta appetizer and their grilled lamb.  Their lamb dishes are always perfectly done.
author: Mrs. K.

description: So many 'bests' here.  Went with a group of friends so we tried a lot of different things.  At least 5 hit my all-time-best list, way more than I'd imagined.  The pan roasted wild ivory salmon was best-ever for me and the woman who ordered it - we all shared.  The chicken breast Milanese was a delightful contrast in colors, textures and flavors (and I loved the capers).  If you get a chance to try the lemon-herb cavatelli pasta - looks odd, tastes fresh and happy.  Again, one of the 'bests' was the vanilla bean creme brulee - moist, delicate, with a thin crust, so yum!  One of the old stand-bys here is the chocolate budino - if you like dark, almost bitter chocolate, you're gonna love this light, impossibly rich dessert.  Your chances of enjoying your meal at Garibaldi's are extremely high!
author: Meganwind E.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in SF.  I know it may sound funny, but I cannot get enough of the olives in olive oil served with bread.  Have ordered the wild boar with pasta on multiple occasions and never disappointed.  Upscale yet relaxed environment.  Will surely keep going back.
author: David N.

description:
They get an extra star for consistency. 

The cocktails are unique and tasty. (Okay, once I ordered some bourbon and kumquat drink that I didn't really like, but every other time, it's been good.) And the food is excellent. If they have the lamb with the tarragon sauce, order it. You'll thank me later.

The service is always good and never snotty, even though I'm usually underdressed compared to the necktie-wearing gentlemen that seem to frequent this place.

Atmosphere is nice -- as some people have noticed, it's got more of an "older person classy" feel than a "younger person trendy" feel, but you can actually hold a conversation without screaming, which is kind of a nice change.

But I think most importantly, my wife and I have been here several times for dinner and we've never ever left feeling like we've had anything less than a really good experience.
author: Todd K.

description:
Exceeded my expectations on 2 visits. The first visit I had the scallops (New England Bay, that is) and they were prepared exquisitely, with a very nice bottle of champagne, a perfect evening dining out. 

The second experience, also with a group of  friends, was a  lovely experience. The food (I had the lamb, a friend had the gnocci, another the salmon and another the sole or halibut?) all agreed -and confirmed-were quite perfectly prepared and savory to the last bite.
author: Agent F.

description:
It's nice to go to a bona fide elegant, good eats restaurant.  There's no extra flare, not dining room theme, just really great tasting food excellently presented. 

I got the salmon (well, I actually ordered the sole, they brought out the salmon, i tasted it, liked it, and decided not to say anything) and my co-eater got the butternut squash.  delightful.  definitely recommend this place if you can make it out this far away from the hustle and bustle of more lively parts of the city.
author: Lindsay T.

description:
Attended a b-day bash for one of my AMGA.

Service was great & I like the ambiance.

Food is great per my co-workers (summer vegetable risotto & pan roasted halibut). Unfortunately, I wasn't hungry so I ordered their chicken caesar salad. I wish they have more to select from the menu when it comes to entree. It's bit pricey, about $40 per person.
author: jubi l.

description: I was here for lunch. The food was great. We started with the Brussels sprouts which had great flavor.  The service actually spoiled the meal.  It took more than 7 minutes to get a waiters attention to get a piece of bread to accompany my salad. When my companion asked for milk in stead of cream for her coffee; it was plunked on the table with an attitude.
author: Carolyn M.

description: What an outstanding meal!  Excellent service and menu and wine list. We enjoyed the tapas style apps. Sea bass was incredible and lamb the best i have ever had.  Cocktails were magnificent, don't miss their version of a classic Manhattan on the rocks with Kirsch and cherries.  Dessert was to die for. Yummmmm.
author: Jim B.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants near my neighborhood. I give A+ on ambience. Decoration of the inside is very my taste. Modern, stylish, black and whitish, and comfortable.

Plus, they always have Prix Fixe Menu course for only $30!!!!!!! I think that's a very good deal.
author: Masa O.

description: Absolutely delightful food. right from olives dip that people had raved about on yelp to the appetizers (we had the butternut squash soup) and the entrees (tuna/pork shoulder/filet mignon) everything was superb. The service was flawless too.
author: A B.

description:
Last Friday night my friends and I took our roommate out to dinner. It was a temporary farewell dinner because this week she had jaw surgery. So we wanted to make sure that she had very good (and crunchy) food.

We had a reservation but still had to wait for about 10 minutes, which wasn't too bad except the bar was full so there was nowhere for the 6 of us to stand. We were seated at a table in the back and I weaseled my way to the booth. I like the inside! But karma, the booth wasn't so comfortable. It would've been great for lounging and watching tv but the seats sank! I found myself constantly having to adjust and by the end of the meal I was lower than the people in chairs across from me.

Service felt slow. But it wasn't. I think Garibaldi's has some strange time warp. We were there for about 2 hours and chatting and enjoying ourselves the entire time. It was not an abnormal amount of time I was just disoriented. I blame the booth.

On to the good stuff: food! My roommate and I shared a caesar with very crunchy croutons. It was really good. Could've used a little more anchovy in the dressing but good for our breath. We all shared calamari. The sauce was really good but the rings were mostly breading. I really liked the jalapenos though. I love spicy. The main courses were almost all great. I had the Chicken Milanese. I didn't really like it. It was nice and moist but I just didn't dig the panko flakes. The mashed potatoes and spinach were fantastic though. Ooh! And the citrus burre blanc sauce with capers was great.

I thought the decor was nice. It was trendy and contemporary without being overdone and ridiculously snooty. It wasn't trying to be too posh but was nearly there.
Overall I really enjoyed it and we had a great night. The server was very nice and attentive. The food was all very good except for my fussy preferences. I plan to go back eventually.
author: Erin G.

description: Friendly, efficient service, good drinks, great food.  Risotto Croquettes were fantastic; chopped salad was very good.  Nice atmosphere and great location near the Vogue theater.  Great place for a dinner and a movie night.  We will return.
author: K. B.

description: Attractive decor. The chicken Milanese was good not great. The risotto croquettes were very delicious. Service was good.  Portions were large so we could take home food for another dinner
author: Susanne L.

description:
This is the second time I've been here and each time has been great.  Service is always good, food has been good too.  And I always seem to meet nice, interesting people sitting beside me.

Our waiter this time gave us a bit of a small pour on one of our wine glasses, but he more than made up for it the following glass.
His wine recommendations were perfect for me.  

Food was well prepared.  Dessert was delicious!  Ambiance is nice, lighting is perfect.  Restaurant overall, is cozy and romantic.

Perfect for date night:)
author: Kat M.

description: cozy atmosphere, yummy food, great neighborhood spot for dinner
author: Samantha A.

description: We used to live around the corner, but had not visited since we moved several months ago.  Went back on a Friday night and remembered why we were fans.  It's not cheap, but the food is consistently excellent, the wine list is interesting, and the cocktail menu is first-rate.  The former beverage manager, Jack, has been promoted to restaurant manager, and his warmth and enthusiasm are a major draw.  So is the ginger julep.  And the fact that, if you show up after 8:30, you can almost always find (1) a parking spot, and (2) a seat.
author: Josh C.

description: I had dinner with my girlfriends last night for the first time. We all ordered 3 course pre fix menu, which costs only $35 and $ 47 with wine paring (2 glasses of wine). Great deal. Portion was large, so I ate all the salad, but could only eat half of the main, which was pork ragu rigatoni. It was pretty rich. Not particularly my favorite, but good, as I like to eat something I never make myself when I eat out. I loved the dessert, though. Pannacotta with gingerbread, some pomegranates sprinkled on it. The wait staff were very attentive and the timing they serve the food was perfect. We had a great time.
author: Foomin U.

description:
I have been to Garibaldi's twice and each time had the Lamb Tenderloin in a tarragon sauce. It is to DIE for. I must say, it is the best lamb dish I  ever ate and was actually heart broken that it was coming to an end. 

The staff was great, a nice wine selection, and the restaurant has a very comfortable atmosphere for its changing high quality dishes. 5 STARS!
author: Ronnie Ray H.

description:
Great neighborhood spot, went there on a weekday for a quiet work dinner and it was really tasty (chopped salad & chicken breast). The wait staff was patient as we talked buisness for a while before we even looked at the menu. Look forward to going back....without the work part of course.

Valet parking is one key part to the experience at Garibaldi's, so many small neighborhood restaurants don't have valet and looking for parking when you are thirsty and hungry is no fun.
author: Nick M.

description:
I've been here quite a few times the last few years and have always been satisfied. It's the quintessential neighborhood go-to place for a nice dinner. If you can't think of anything else and have a guest in town, dinner with a business associate or a 3rd date, Garibaldi's never fails. This a place that caters to all age groups who simply want a great meal without emptying their wallets completely.

This July I especially enjoyed their farmer's prix fixe menu -- to die for. After a few appetizers (which were awesome), we received the tasting portions. I asked the waiter if they accidentally brought us two tastings by mistake, but they didn't! They almost doubled it at no charge. We also had a few glasses of wine which were healthy pours in the bigger glasses they have there (usually they only give you those if you bring a bottle). 

Now, October is upon us with a new chef and new staff and things have changed. The original, traditional menu items you could have depended on were missing and their menu changes nightly now (why, oh, why?). 

Anyway, I ordered the pork last visit and was not impressed at all. For $28 I got an overcooked piece of pork (poorly cut, too), dry rice, some charred grapes, a weak pour on a $12 wine (Napa does better!) and a half-decent salad. Not to mention the tasting menu for October was not of the least bit interesting -- maybe I'll try the Autumn special and hopefully my review will go back to being 4 stars.

Garibaldi's where have you gone -- you're ready for some change!* 

*No presidential candidate has endorsed this message.
author: Tom W.

description: In all the years, consistency is there again and again!  Several things result in a not-quite perfect 5-star review (sorry, John!):  restaurant wasn't over-crowded but wait-staff seemed super busy...they were pleasant and willingly pitched-in for each other, and perhaps their slightly less "wet blanket" approach is overall better than someone coming every 2 minutes to check in, but there was a slight feeling that everyone was a bit distracted.  The food was first-class, in portions and in level of attention and cooking  Perhaps we didn't thoroughly read menu, as my guest found the lamb seasoning to be extremely overwhelming and a bit sweet (very Middle East tasting)--maybe a better description on the menu?  or taper back on the herbs?  I'll see how it tastes as left-overs.  Chocolate Budino was outrageous!!  Nice to be back for a meal.  Like the 3 little tables right at the bar, perfect for a more casual, and fewer dishes, meal.
author: Cecily D.

description: This is a wonderful restauant, one of my favs in San Franicsco.  The lighting, the food, everything is always wonderful. We've taken friends and family when visiting SF and they always love it. We also celebrated here when we got engaged.
author: JULIE V.

description: Exceeded our expectations. The Dine About Town menu was excellent. The Cucumber Martini was one of the best I've had. A wonderful place for a special occasion.
author: Maria V.

description:
Came here recently, not sure if they changed chef but the food was a BIG disappointment.

Quality and freshness is in question.
author: Kate L.

description: Had a lovely experience: Big portions, nice waiters, everything was seasoned well. No hype or tricks, just solid food.
author: Dasha O.

description: They may be pricy, but if thats a problem then just don't go here. They have really good food though, and if you want to try it but it is a bit out of your price range, then just eat the bar food. I suggest the hummus or their burgers, but don't get too many drinks cuz that will rack up the tab real fast!
author: Corie F.

description: Friendly staff and quaint atmosphere make this a perfect spot for an intimate dinner. There were two of us, and we started with a calamari appetizer, which I must admit was my fault for not noticing it was not "fried" calamari. Needless to say, was not that impressed with sautéed calamari. (a lil too fishy and squishy for my unrefined palate)  For the main course, the salmon was a nice dish but cooked with a cranberry sauce and caramelized carrots which was a lil on the sweet side but very good if that's your cup of tea. The chicken however, was absolutely amazing! Not sure how it's possible to make such a simple chicken and mashed potatoes dish taste so good, but bravo Garibaldi's, bravo! Highly recommend it!
author: Patrick N.

description:
Heaven in a bowl.

Those words were used to describe the caramel brownie sundae near the end of this memorable meal. That's no hyperbole, it really was that good. As was everything else.

Before getting to the rest of the food, a note on the overall ambiance and atmosphere. Laurel Heights is a trek, especially coming from the Mission. But it is so worth it. Garibaldi's oozes charm and sophistication, a place you want to save for a very important date, or to celebrate a special occasion with friends and family. There is a confidence in how Garibaldi's operates, and you immediately know you are in very capable hands.

And those capable hands are definitely doing some of their best work in the kitchen. As you've read, dessert was fantastic. So was everything else. We started with a few appetizers, with the watermelon salad, sweet corn soup, green beans and meatballs each being standouts. This is definitely where going with a group was helpful - we sampled a bit of everything

For the main course I went with the halibut, which was surrounded by black rice, corn and peas in a tomato sauce. This was a choice I do not regret. Simply outstanding. And there were no complaints from around the table, with the lamb being a particular favorite.

Full disclosure - a good friend of mine is sous chef, which no doubt had me biased towards enjoying everything. If anything, he simply gives Garibaldi's an unattainable sixth star. Judged on merit alone, this is five stars across the board. Go and enjoy.
author: Jason B.

description: Professional service, noise level appropriate, relaxing, great, fresh food. Wonderful neighborhood restaurant. Bar menu is limited. Best burger in town. I go back again and again!
author: Banthehoodie A.

description: I came here for brunch, which they began recently serving, last weekend. It was very good. The french toast with apple compote was truly outstanding, and the bacon it came with was cooked to perfection (crispy edges, meaty middle). The menu definitely featured a few items that called to me, so I'll be back for sure! My one and only gripe: my first glass of orange juice was delicious and fresh squeezed; my second glass came straight out of a Naked Juice or Odwalla jug (I saw it being poured), and tasted as you'd expect. At $4/glass, that makes for a great profit margin! Anyway, I'm guessing they'd run out (it was the end of service), but I would have appreciated a heads-up or on that one.
author: Kiesha R.

description:
this is a 3.5 star review 

a lovely (albeit bland) little restaurant tucked away in a swanky neighborhood. I have been here twice, and the first time was for the dine about town menu. 

I went with a dining companion who had gluten allergy, which made it impossible for her to have the set menu. She told the server who assured her that it would be more than possible to make changes, and that she would be sure to verify each item. After the soup came out, (cream of mushroom) we double checked that it didn't have gluten. 

Blank stare from the server. "Um you wanted what?" 

I've been in the service industry, so I certainly empathize but the same blank stare for both the entree and desert was enough to knock a star off. 

The other half a star is certainly for ambiance. I think I age about 25 years after every visit. At least now I can look into my "Driving Miss Daisy" days. Dinner can be a bit stuffy and pretentious but i think that goes with the neighborhood territory. 

Any lamb dish (loin lamb salad) i have ever had there has been absolutely scrumptious and please save room for the most decadent chocolate budino EVER. Feel free to miss the dried out sole and the under seasoned heirloom tomato salad.
author: Ali R.

description:
always pretty tasty, although tonight was a bit salty on everything.  their oakland location is better.  the lamb is their signature dish, the pork shank is fairly nice, and the scallops with black rice are very good.  chocolate budino is a tasty dessert.

recommended, but a bit overpriced.  i wouldnt go out of your way to go here, but its still a pretty solid choice.
author: Junglist S.

description: Came here for DAT lunch.  The lamb salad offered for DAT was good. My friend ordered off the menu and her pork tenderloin was perfectly cooked.  I had to take off stars for the service... our waitress was cold, service was slow, and then they lost my friends credit card (which eventually showed up).
author: Angelique B.

description:
My husband and I have been here twice and it was one of our favorite restaurants.  Definitely get the Farmer's Market option with the wine pairing.  It has an interesting description, but has always been excellent and different.  The wine pairings are perfect.

We also have liked the lamb and the chicken that are regular items on the menu.
The beet antipasta place and the risotto croquettes were also delicious.

On our first visit we saw Nancy Pelosi here and she was celebrating her 70th birthday....apparently this is one of her favorite restaurants and I can see why.
author: Cathryn L.

description: I truly enjoyed everything about this restaurant. The decor is ambient and modern (although the chadeliers should be raised one inch and the bottom covered with fabric) The food was perfectly portioned. The flavors were amazing. I had the Halibut - which was great. I will definetly go back
author: Lindsey S.
